title: taoiseach says us interest in ni makes a difference at delicate post brexit time
story: US president Joe Biden spoke in glowing terms of his relationship with Ireland during the bilateral meeting with Taoiseach Micheál Martin. Video: RTÉ			                                        					 Taoiseach Micheál Martin speaking with US president Joe Biden via video link on St Patrick’s Day. Photograph:  Julien Behal PhotographyPA WireThe “eyes and interest” of the United States continue to “make a difference at a delicate time” for post-Brexit Northern Ireland, Taoiseach Micheál Martin has said.Speaking at a virtual meeting of the traditional Friends of Ireland St Patrick’s Day event, Mr Martin told Irish-American politicians that there has been “deep appreciation of the importance of the balances and nuances” of Northern Ireland’s Belfast Agreement in Washington since Brexit.This was “an appreciation that we do not take for granted”, the Taoiseach said in an address that touched on the tensions caused by Brexit in the North and between the EU and UK.Mr Martin said the Government always knew that the UK’s departure from the EU would “create strains and complications, especially in Northern Ireland”, and that the “voices” of Irish-American politicians within the caucus “helped pave the way” for the Brexit withdrawal deal.The Northern Ireland protocol within that agreement was “an agreed, balanced compromise” and was “the only way” to manage complexities in Northern Ireland and to avoid a hard border.“Implementing the protocol involves change and sometimes it takes time for people to adjust to new ways of doing things. The protocol has only been in operation since the start of the year,” Mr Martin said.“I have always known that there would inevitably be bumps and wrinkles along the way. That is why the agreement itself contains mechanisms through which any difficulties can be resolved.” For the protocol to succeed and deliver benefits for the people of Northern Ireland, there has to be a relationship between the UK and the EU “based on trust and good faith”, he said, in a reference to the tensions over the UK government’s decision to delay border checks for British businesses.Proud memberIn a video address, US president Joe Biden said that he was a proud member of the Friends of Ireland caucus when he was a US senator and paid tribute to his former colleagues who “tended to the flame of Irish-American relationships – a flame that glows ever brighter every single day”.Democratic congressman Richie Neal, a co-chair of the Friends of Ireland group, said in his online remarks that the 1998 Belfast Agreement underpinning the Northern Ireland peace process “remains the only way forward on the island of Ireland – there is simply no plan B”. Mr Biden quoted his favourite poet Seamus Heaney and his poem The Cure at Troy, which he has quoted in public for years, saying: “We have a chance to make hope and history rhyme.” The Friends of Ireland caucus of Irish-American politicians marks its 40th anniversary this year. Normally the Taoiseach would attend the Friends of Ireland St Patrick’s Day lunch alongside the president at the US Capitol – one of only two occasions in Washington’s political calendar when the president travels to Capitol Hill – but the Covid-19 pandemic forced the event online. title: angela merkel ditches hasty easter lockdown plan
story: German chancellor Angela Merkel speaking in the  Bundestag on Wednesday. Photograph: Clemens BilanEPA Chancellor Angela Merkel ditched a plan agreed on Tuesday for an extended Easter holiday to try to break a third wave of the coronavirus pandemic, apologising to lockdown-weary Germans after the hastily-conceived plan triggered a backlash.At talks that ran into the early hours of Tuesday, Dr Merkel and the leaders of Germany’s 16 states had agreed to call on citizens to stay at home for five days over the Easter holidays, declaring April 1st and April 3rd as extra “rest days”.The measure would have meant all shops, including essential ones, closing for an extra day.“The idea of an Easter shutdown was drafted with the best of intentions. We urgently need to stop and reverse the third wave of the pandemic,” the chancellor said.But it was not possible to implement the hastily agreed measures so quickly, she added, and apologised for added uncertainty that it had raised for Germans.Her comments came against a backdrop of growing public frustration with the conservative-led government over the slow rollout of Covid-19 vaccines and extended lockdown measures.“No plan, no clue, no courage,” ran a headline in the online edition of the mass-selling Bild daily above a picture of Dr Merkel and two state leaders.Dietmar Bartsch, head of the opposition Left Party, called for a vote of no-confidence in Dr Merkel, telling newspapers of the Funke media group: “We now have a veritable crisis of confidence in the political leadership of the country.”A poll released on Wednesday showed support for Dr Merkel’s conservatives slumping to its lowest in over a year ahead of a national election in September. Dr Merkel, who has led Germany since 2005, will stand down before the vote.At the talks earlier this week, Dr Merkel had pushed for a reversal of plans for a gradual re-opening of the economy agreed earlier this month following a sharp rise in the infection rate.But state premiers pushed back, only agreeing to call on citizens to stay at home over the Easter holidays.‘Bit of reasoning’The move drew criticism from all sides, with businesses lamenting the extended lockdown and medical experts saying the new measures were not tough enough to prevent the exponential spread of more infectious variants of the virus.The HDE association of retailers welcomed Dr Merkel’s reversal on Wednesday, noting that closing stores for an extra day ahead of Easter would have led to logistical problems and prompted shoppers to rush to stock up earlier.“With today’s decision, a bit of reason is returning to coronavirus policy,” said HDE president Stefan Genth. The CDU suffered historic defeats in two state elections this month, hit by public frustration over the slow vaccine rollout and the extended lockdown measures, as well as a scandal over the procurement of face masks.The conservative bloc has yet to settle on a chancellor candidate, and is already missing the “Merkel bonus” she has brought them with four consecutive national election victories.Germany, which has a population of 83 million, reported another 15,813 infections on Wednesday, bringing the total to 2,690,523, while the death toll rose by 248 to 75,212.The number of cases per 100,000 in the last seven days, which the government has used as a key metric to decide on lockdown steps, was stable at 108. – ReutersStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: european commission proposes tougher controls on covid 19 vaccine exports
story: European Commission Vice-President Valdis Dombrovskis told a news conference the export authorisation mechanism was not targeting any specific country. Photograph: Stephanie LecocqAFPGetty ImagesThe European Union refined its rules on the export of Covid-19 vaccines on Wednesday, giving it a clearer right to block shipments to countries such as Britain with higher inoculation rates and to those not exporting their own vaccine doses.The move risks stoking post-Brexit tensions with London, which has warned Brussels against “vaccine nationalism”.EU trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis told a news conference the export authorisation mechanism was not targeting any specific country.The European Commission, which oversees trade policy for the 27 EU members, set out a proposal expanding existing measures that seek to ensure planned exports by drugmakers do not threaten already reduced EU supply.The granting of export licences will be based on reciprocity and “proportionality” - the epidemiological situation, vaccination rate and access to vaccines in the destination country.EU officials say export restrictions could also kick in if companies do respect quarterly contracts but backload supplies at the end of the period.Mr Dombrovskis said the new rules did not create a detailed algorithm on authorisations and requests would be considered on a case-by-case basis.The scheme will also widen the net to include 17 neighbouring countries, including Israel, Norway and Switzerland. Previously exempted, exports to these countries will also need authorisation.Alarming third waveThe proposal is set to be a topic of discussion on Thursday at an online summit of EU leaders, whose countries are struggling with a third wave of infections that has prompted harder lockdowns amid a slow rollout of vaccines.EU Health Commissioner Stella Kyriakides said the situation in many EU countries was “alarming”, with increasing cases in 19 EU members and rising fatalities in eight.While France, Germany and Italy broadly support tighter export curbs on those who do not reciprocate, countries including the Netherlands, Belgium and Ireland are more cautious about cutting off Britain.A French presidential adviser said the EU should be not be a sort of “useful idiot” in the battle against the virus.Taoiseach Micheal Martin said any EU restrictions on vaccine exports would be a “retrograde step”.A UK government spokesperson said all countries were fighting the same pandemic and that Britain would continue to work with European partners to deliver the vaccine rollout.The Commission insists it is not an export ban and says priority systems set up for vaccinating citizens in other countries are de facto bans even if they are not called that.The bloc said it had exported 43 million doses to 33 countries since the end of January, including 10.9 million to Britain. Some 380 export requests were granted and only one was blocked - from Italy to Australia.The EU has so far authorised four Covid-19 vaccines. AstraZeneca doses were supposed to be the vaccination for the masses, but deliveries have and will be far lower than initially indicated.EU countries have given a dose to about 10 per cent of their adult populations and have watched Britain provide at least one vaccination to over half of all adults, suffering almost no delivery problems, despite the same plants officially supplying both.The Commission proposal will come into force unless a “qualified majority” of EU members oppose it, which is very unlikely. –ReutersEverything you need to know about the Covid-19 outbreakStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: chicago suburb leads country first reparations black residents
story: The grand Dutch colonial houses in downtown Evanston give way to small clapboard homes with postage stamp gardens as you cross the city’s invisible border.The clustering of the Chicago suburb’s black population into the triangle-shaped Fifth Ward - nestled between the old sewage canal to the east and railroad tracks to the west - is not by accident, but by design.A discriminatory century-old housing practice, known as “redlining”, limited the areas black people could live, helping turn Evanston into one of the most segregated cities in the US.Evanston’s city council on Monday took a huge step towards repairing the resulting damage suffered by black families by voting to award reparations, making it the first in the country to do so.Those who can show they are descendants of an Evanstonian who lived here between 1919 and 1969, or directly experienced housing discrimination themselves in the decades since, will now be eligible for $25,000 (£18,000) grants to either go towards home repairs or a mortgage.The decision comes amid an increasingly urgent national conversation on how to tackle systematic racial inequity following the police killing of George Floyd and other black Americans last year.“Right now, the whole world is looking at Evanston, Illinois. This is a moment like none other that we’ve ever seen, and it’s a good moment,” said Ron Daniels, president of the National African American Reparations Commission, after the vote.The council’s aldermen hope Evanston will become a model for other cities and states grappling with whether to pursue their own reparations programs.Growing up in the Fifth Ward, Robin Rue Simmons, who championed the bill, remembers the first time she realised the stark difference between the surrounding neighbourhoods.Visiting a white friend's home as a child she noticed “the streets were wider. The trees were taller. The homes were bigger and brighter. 'My family worked just as hard, why didn’t we live like this?’” she asked herself.Evanston’s first African American residents began arriving in the 1860s following the abolishment of slavery. By the late 1940s, the population had grown and white officials became anxious about the value of their homes.The city began demolishing houses belonging to black residents that were outside of the Fifth Ward, forcing them to move to the redlined boundaries.According to a recent report by local historian Morris “Dino” Robinson, homes in the area had smaller lot sizes, and often went without electricity and water.“There are still realtors who refer to the redlining maps to steer people into certain communities,” Mr Robinson, founder of the Shorefront Legacy Center, which is dedicated to chronicling local black history, told The . “All that's changed is it just became harder to prove.”Despite the city passing a fair housing law in 1968, estate agents continued to refuse to show black buyers properties outside the triangle, while banks generally refused to loan.Today, about 16 per cent of its 75,000 residents are black and the majority live in the one-square-mile neighbourhood.White people in Evanston make nearly double the income and their homes are worth twice as much as their black neighbours’, according to the most recent US Census. Of the 218 mortgages in Evanston issued by one major bank in 2018, 150 went to whites and 17 to blacks - numbers far out of line with a 65 per cent to 15 per cent split in the population as a whole.“I’m just glad that now there is a recognition that harm was done,” said teacher Sara Diggs, 69, outside the house her grandparents bought in the Fifth Ward in 1941. “Acknowledgment of wrongs done is the first part of healing.It's not perfect, but no first prototype is. Evanston is making history and we're part of it, said Ms Diggs, who qualifies for the pay-out.The will to repair the damage caused by America’s so-called original sin has never been greater.Last week, the Jesuit order of Catholic priests pledged $100 million to benefit the descendants of the enslaved people it once owned.Barack Obama came out in February and publicly backed reparations as “justified” - something he said he was unable to do while serving as the country’s first black president.“There’s not much question that the wealth of this country, the power of this country was built in significant part, not exclusively, maybe not even the majority of it, but a large portion of it was built on the backs of slaves,” he said.President Joe Biden’s senior adviser Cedric Richmond has said he was “going to start acting now” by looking into national reparations plans.Mr Biden, who has black voters to thank for his 2020 election win, has himself supported the idea of federal study into reparations, though has not expressed full backing for legislation.Congress has debated a bill that would create a commission to study the reparations issue more closely. The bill, House Resolution 40, was last considered in 2019, and it refers to the Civil War-era broken promise to give former slaves “40 acres and a mule.” The proposal for reparations has found overwhelming support in Evanston, which is known for its liberal politics.The bill passed late Monday night 8-1. The aldermen voted to allow the funding for the reparations to be drawn largely from revenue from a 3 per cent tax the city collects on the sale of recreational cannabis.The sole dissenting city official did not object to reparations in theory but said the current program fails to give residents enough of a say in how they will be distributed.Cicely Fleming, who is black, said the focus on housing confirmed negative stereotypes that the poorest “can’t handle their money” and discriminates against people who may be due reparations but either do not own a home or do not plan to purchase one.Other detractors told The  they do not see housing assistance as a credible form of reparations.“True reparations repair you – you get a chance to say what it is that repairs you,” said Rose Cannon, a member of the group Evanston Rejects Racist Reparations.“There aren’t even houses in Evanston which you can buy with a $25,000 down payment, a lot of people are going to end up being very disappointed,” said Ms Cannon, a 73-year-old resident of the city. “These are absolutely not the reparations we are entitled to.”Outside Evanston, there is still plenty of scepticism about the need for reparations.An Ipsos poll taken in June 2020, at the height of racial justice protests, found only one in five respondents agreed the US should pay damages to descendants of enslaved people.Some opponents ask whether taxpayers can afford to pay out what could be billions, or even trillions, of dollars. Others question how eligibility for such programs would be determined, whether by race, ancestry or evidence of discrimination.It is an issue that has long rankled the Republican Party. Mitch McConnell, Senate Minority Leader, publicly opposed the idea of reparations in 2019, arguing “none of us currently living are responsible” and that electing the first African American president showed the country had moved on.Conservative lawyers in Washington DC have already threatened to sue the city for the program, claiming it is “racially discriminatory”, “unfair” and “unconstitutional”.But this has done little to dampen Evanston’s day.In the Fifth Ward on Tuesday, many were quietly celebrating. “It may be a small step, but it’s what it symbolises,” said Ms Diggs.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: ethical questions around covid vaccination children
story: For more than a year, Britain has faced one ethical dilemma after another. Should the most vulnerable be expected to stay home so the rest of society can function more normally?  How can the balance be struck against protecting human life and supporting the economy to sustain it?Now ministers are facing one of the most controversial questions of all. Should children be vaccinated?Unlike many common viruses – and the diseases for which children are routinely immunised – Covid has largely spared children from its direct effects, causing few fatalities or severe cases across the population. Yet health officials are nevertheless contemplating whether it could be necessary – and ethical – to recommend routine Covid vaccination of the under-18s. If trials, now ongoing, show the jabs are safe and effective, the programme could be rolled out as soon as August, government sources say. Prof Adam Finn, professor of paediatrics at the Bristol Children's Vaccine Centre, is one of the scientists involved in the research.  Stressing that no decision has been made – nor will be until there are results from trials – he says any case for vaccinating children would not be based on the threat infection poses to them. Instead, vaccination of under-18s would be an attempt to reduce their role transmitting the virus and thus bolster herd immunity across the population, says Prof Finn, a member of the Government's joint committee on vaccination and immunisation (JCVI).He told The : You are left with an ethical question, whether it is ok to immunise children for the benefit of adults. But in fact given that schools being closed has done the greatest harm to children, and that vaccinating children would help to keep schools open, I think there is an ethical case.If a Covid vaccine were to be given to children it might seem logical to do so at schools, which already deal with jabs for flu, MMR and HPV, which protects against cervical cancer. Normally we do immunisations at school, as it's the best way to get good coverage, but obviously we are in exceptional times so nothing is a given, says Prof Finn.Current preparations are about covering all the bases, he says, so that if the decision was taken to roll out jabs to children, the system is able to do so. The Government's current schedule says all adults should have been offered their first vaccine by the end of July. At this point, if the programme is extended, a choice may need to be made between two key competing priorities, the old and the young.Government scientists have said booster jabs – a third dose – are likely to be needed to protect against new Covid variants. Earlier this month, Professor Anthony Harnden, the acting chairman of the JCVI, suggested that this could be rolled out in August or September rather than later in the year, because of this worry about a large third wave affecting the vulnerable elderly.He told the British Medical Journal: I think we're likely to make a bold decision to recommend a booster dose, even if we haven't got all the evidence of the necessity, just because I think the consequences of not immunising with the booster dose are so big. If it's proved that it's needed months later, it may be too late.But this week Sir Patrick Vallance, the chief scientific adviser, suggested booster jabs would be more likely to be offered later in the year. Potentially, this could leave a crucial window in which children are offered the jab, with government sources suggesting this could come as soon as August. Sir Patrick told a Downing Street press conference on Tuesday: There will be a need to think about booster jabs for vaccines in the autumn I suspect, particularly thinking about getting a high level of immunity to cover things over the winter.So far, in Britain’s vaccine rollout, the focus has been on the most vulnerable. Offering jabs to all over-50s covers the groups which account for 99 per cent of all Covid deaths.But amid growing concern that a third wave will wash up from our shores” from Europe and provide a breeding ground for new variants, arguments that a strategy to push for maximum immunity across the population – including children – are growing louder. Last month, Prof John Edmunds, of the Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (Sage), said children should be vaccinated against Covid as fast as we can to prevent a rise in new infections after lockdown is lifted. Prof Edmunds said there was a significant risk of a resurgence of the virus until everyone in the country, including children, had been vaccinated.Parents may also look at it in a wider family context – that vaccinating children may also be the best way to protect granny. Scientists have pointed out that even if all elderly people have two doses of vaccine, protection levels of between 82 and 95 per cent mean some will remain exposed to danger. New variants may reduce the effectiveness of jabs, further increasing this gap. Nevertheless, while trials of Covid vaccines for children have been inundated by families keen to sign up, some parents may feel uneasy about the prospect of giving children jabs which are not about their direct clinical protection. Prof Finn is involved in a key clinical trial by the University of Oxford, testing the safety and efficacy of the OxfordAstrazeneca jab on 300 children aged between six and 17.The study started last month with children at the upper end of the range. Safety data is expected shortly, before the programme extends to younger children, and efficacy data is expected by summer.On Tuesday, Prof Finn said that if the rollout of vaccines is extended to children, it is likely to start with teenagers. Israel, the country with the highest proportion of vaccinated citizens globally, is already giving jabs to 16- and 17-year-olds.If it does turn out to be necessary to immunise children, I think it is more likely that we would prioritise teenagers over younger children, simply because the evidence we have at the moment is that transmission of the virus is more likely to occur from and between teenagers – who are a little bit more like adults,” Prof Finn said. But he added that evidence is needed about what proportion of the population requires immunisation to produce effective herd immunity and suppress circulation of the virus.We need to have a clear understanding of how efficiently the vaccines actually interrupt infection and transmission, and that evidence is still on its way, he said. A spokesman for the Department of Health said: While clinical trials are under way to test the efficacy and safety of Covid-19 vaccines in children and young adults, these trials have not concluded yet. We will be guided by the advice of our experts on these issues, including the independent JCVI.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: eu targets uk vaccine export ban aimed countries high vaccination
story: Brussels on Wednesday targeted Britain with beefed up rules to impose vaccine export bans on countries with higher vaccination rates than the EU. Britain has far outstripped the EU in vaccination, giving a first dose to more than half its adult population. The bloc, in the grip of a third Covid wave, has so far managed only 12 per cent. The European Commission – which has faced criticism as frustration at the slow rollout mounts in Europe – said the revised vaccine transparency mechanism would also target countries that manufactured coronavirus jabs but did not export them to the EU. Valdis Dombrovskis, the EU's trade commissioner, said the EU had exported about 10.9 million vaccines, mostly from the Belgian Pfizer plant, to the UK, but Britain had not sent any jabs to the bloc. So if we discuss reciprocity, solidarity, global responsibility, it's clear that we also need to look at those aspects of responsibility and proportionality, he said.  Brussels is furious with AstraZeneca after the company announced a string of supply shortfalls of millions of doses. Pharmaceutical companies failing to meet contractual obligations are also targeted in the revisions to rules forcing manufacturers to ask the commission for permission to export outside the bloc. Mr Dombrovskis and Stella Kyriakides, the EU health commissioner, denied the ban was a punishment for Britain's vaccination success as Belgium announced a new intensified lockdown. But asked by The  which country could be hardest hit by the measure, Mr Dombrovskis gave the UK as an example. The trade commissioner also did not deny that Pfizer exports to Britain could be blocked, which could spark a vaccine trade war if the UK retaliates by blocking exports of raw materials to Pfizer. He said decisions would be made on a case by case basis according to the new criteria. Ms Kyriakides said: We're dealing with a pandemic and this is not seeking to punish any countries. We are the strongest supporters of global solidarity.The commission has already threatened to block the export of millions of AstraZeneca vaccines from the company's Halix plant in Leiden, the Netherlands, to the UK. Ursula von der Leyen, the commission president, wants Boris Johnson to release AstraZeneca from its contractual agreement of first refusal on supplies from the company's two British factories so it can supply the bloc. The commission argues that its contract with AstraZeneca counts the two factories as EU suppliers. The Halix factory cannot currently supply the EU, pending regulatory clearance from the European Medicines Agency. The new rules were revealed ahead of an EU summit on Thursday, at which the bloc's 27 leaders will discuss possible export bans amid UK-EU negotiations to try and avoid the ban. If leaders back them, they are expected to come into force soon afterwards and last for six weeks. Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, on Tuesday ruled out a blanket ban on vaccine exports but said she supported Mrs von der Leyen's targeted ban on AstraZeneca. Germany, along with France and Italy, has strengthened its lockdown, and Berlin is putting pressure on the European Commission to buy Russian Sputnik vaccines to ramp up vaccinations. Mr Johnson is understood to be prepared to share vaccine supplies from the Halix factory as UK officials try to convince Brussels to drop the threat.  Britain also wants its investment in developing the AstraZeneca vaccine to be taken into account in any deal with Brussels. The commission turned down a British offer of trilateral talks with AstraZeneca to find a solution to the stand-off, arguing that it was not possible because Brussels had begun legal action against the British-Swedish pharmaceutical company.A Government spokesperson said: We are all fighting the same pandemic and we will continue to work with our European partners to deliver the vaccine rollout.  We remain confident in our supplies and are on track to offer first doses to all over-50s by April 15 and all adults by the end of July.Italy became the first country to trigger the vaccine export mechanism, introduced in January in the opening salvos of the EU's row with AstraZeneca, and blocked 250,000 of the firm's jabs from being exported to Australia earlier this month.Italian authorities raided a vaccine factory amid fears that 29 million AstraZeneca jabs meant for developing countries and Belgium were hidden supplies intended for the UK, it emerged on Wednesday.The commission said it had received 380 export requests to 33 different destinations for a total of around 43 million doses and had granted all except the one shipment to Australia.The new rules also remove exemptions for non-EU members such as Norway and Switzerland, as well as Israel and Serbia, which have far outstripped the bloc in vaccinations. Developing countries that are part of the Covax vaccination programme remain exempt from the mechanism, which the commissioners insisted was not an export ban. More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: eu vaccine posturing cant disguise fact continent faces catastrophic
story: Only a small minority of Europeans have yet contracted Covid-19 or been vaccinated against it. Given this fact, and how highly transmissible the virus is, this means there is now another wave of infections on the Continent. Desperate attempts to extend restrictions are being met by lockdown fatigue. Recriminations abound as the hospitals fill and the death toll mounts.No wonder, then, that there is an effort to shift blame. More widespread vaccination could have been the answer but the EU did not start early enough. Legend on the Continent has it that AstraZeneca has met its supply schedule to the UK but is behind in supplying the EU. This is simply untrue. AstraZeneca got way behind here as well.Last May, when the UK made its original agreement with the firm, we were supposed to receive 30 million doses during 2020. By September the production schedule was so behind that this had been downgraded to 4 million. In the end we didn’t begin rolling out the AstraZeneca vaccine until January 2021 (and indeed still seem not to have received 30 million even now). That lag did affect us – badly. If we had been able to start vaccinating millions of people per week in November, far fewer would have died in our DecemberJanuary wave.The EU now faces similar AstraZeneca production delays at Continental plants. It is not for the UK, having already had its supply severely delayed and many people die as a result, to have its supply slowed even further.There is talk of the EU blocking Dutch AstraZeneca exports to Britain. We do not currently get supply from the Netherlands, though reportedly we might do so in the future. More careless EU talk of banning Pfizer exports has taken a back seat, as the company pointed out publicly that its EU production relies on materials supplied from the UK, so the EU is in no position to commandeer that supply chain.None of these bans is likely to be implemented to an extent that aims at anything more than symbolism. Really they represent efforts by EU leaders to signal to their citizens that vaccine delays are not their fault and that the perfidious British are in some vague way to blame. One doubts such meaningless posturing will be of much comfort to European citizens as they face more lockdowns and prolonged risk of hospitalisation or death.In Britain the headlines scream that we face the risk of a third wave imported from Europe. But with half our population going to have received one dose of an incredibly effective vaccine by the end of this month, with 25-30 per cent of us already having had the disease, and with strong restrictions in place even after we start easing lockdown, there is no real risk of this, barring a vaccine-escaping variant.We may feel the political and economic implications of the Continent’s third wave, however: fewer exports for our firms, financial spillovers (if a new Eurozone crisis were to occur, for example). It may disrupt sports events here this summer (the European Football Championship), and our holiday plans. But as matters stand we face very little disease risk from there.The vaccines work against all known variants. The evidence is that they are almost miraculously effective at stopping the disease causing serious ill-health, amazingly effective at preventing transmission, and that even onward transmission is likely to be impeded for those few vaccinated people who do become ill. Even with the disruption of imports from India and threats of blockades from the EU, Boris Johnson remains so confident that we will meet our target of vaccinating all adults by the end of July that he repeated it yesterday.If the UK had opened up a little more from March 8, if the EU had not been so belligerent about vaccines, and if EU leaders had not so effectively spread anti-vaxxer myths about the AstraZeneca vaccine (and consequently damaged EU citizens' trust in it), there might well be pressure in the UK for us to send vaccines to help out Europe. It would have been reasonable to ask: Why are we vaccinating healthy 30-year-olds when 80-year-old Spanish, French and Czech citizens are dying? But there is now no argument for our risking any Summer exit wave of hospitalisations in Britain (even if it ought to be modest and manageable) by sending vaccines to the Continent that it simply will not use.Europe's third wave is a tragedy, and we may face political, economic and cultural consequences. But it presents no current disease threat to us, no threat of disrupting our roadmap to relaxation, and, sadly, our ability to help is limited: even if we were to put our own citizens at greater risk by sending vaccines to the Continent, Europe's leaders seem incapable of using them. More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: israel could heading right wing government history
story: Benjamin Netanyahu has failed to emerge as the clear winner of Tuesday night’s elections, raising the prospect of him relying on hardline religious movements to secure a coalition government.Initial results show that the prime minister’s Likud party has won the largest number of seats but is set to fall short of the 61 seats required for a majority in the fourth election in Israel in two years. It means that Mr Netanyahu may need to court the hard-Right Religious Zionism group and possibly newcomer Islamist movement Ra’am - among others -  in coalition talks that are expected to be a complex, lengthy process. An alliance with Religious Zionism would be controversial as it includes the far-Right party Otzma Yehudit - Jewish Power in Hebrew - whose leader has expressed admiration for a mass-murderer who gunned down 29 Palestinians in the early 1990s.Itamar Ben Gvir, whose faction is set to enter the Israeli parliament for the first time, is notorious for displaying a picture of the killer, Baruch Goldstein, in his living room. He has also called for the deportation of Arab-Israeli citizens who are not loyal to Israel. Mr Ben Gvir agreed to take down the inflammatory photograph in January after criticism from Naftali Bennett, another prominent right-winger. Goldstein committed the murders in 1994 in Hebron and since then his grave has become a pilgrimage site of sorts for Jewish extremists. Mr Ben Gvir has not yet confirmed if he would be willing to join forces with Mr Netanyahu. But the Religious Zionism movement his party is part of is projected to win around seven seats, which could prove decisive in building a coalition. On the other end of of the spectrum, the Arab Islamist party Ra’am - otherwise known as the United Arab List - could also prove to be an important player, for either Mr Netanyahu or an alliance of anti-Netanyahu parties.Initial results say Ra’am, which supports the two-state solution and the creation of a Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital, is set to meet the threshold for entering the Israeli parliament.Whoever reaches out to us, we will work with them, leader Mansour Abbas told reporters yesterday.However, he has insisted he “isn’t in the pocket” of Mr Netanyahu or his enemies. There are also reports of tensions in Likud, Mr Netanyahu’s party, as to whether it should join forces with Islamists to produce a government. Even so, the results suggest that fervently religious Jewish and Muslim factions may end up playing a key role in talks on who will become Israel’s next prime minister. Tuesday night’s election was widely regarded as a referendum on Mr Netanyahu, who is facing a corruption trial but has also won plaudits for his high-speed vaccinations campaign. But, much like previous polls, the results are showing a mixed picture and may yet lead to a fifth election being called later this year. Yesh Atid, the main rival to Mr Netanyahu’s Likud party, is set to win around 15 seats and maintains hopes of building a coalition against Israel’s longest serving prime minister. This would likely require support from left-wing parties such as Labor, as well as the Blue and White faction led by Benny Gantz, which failed to unseat Mr Netanyahu last year. The results were also disappointing for right-wing rivals of Mr Netanyahu, who hoped to finally step out of his shadow. Gideon Sa’ar, the leader of the new party New Hope, is only set to secure around five seats and has firmly ruled out a coalition with Mr Netanyahu. Meanwhile Naftali Bennett, the leader of Yamina, is projected to win seven seats, a lower result than he hoped but one that may potentially allow him to prop up the Likud party. This suggests that Mr Netanyahu, known to his supporters as “Bibi,” continues to be Israel’s most popular right-wing leader by a wide margin, despite the uncertainty of the results. More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to title: snps incompetence now record remains accountable no one
story: The Scottish Conservatives made a strategic blunder last week when they announced, even before the report by the Salmond inquiry committee had been published, that they would table a motion of no confidence in the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon.Perhaps they thought there was some kind of race between them and Scottish Labour to see which of the main opposition parties would be first to hit the no-confidence button, assuming that the winner would earn the loyalty and support of a swathe of voters sick of the SNP government.But what is the point in such a vote if you know in advance you’re going to lose? And the motion was always going to fall, even with the support of Labour MSPs, who chose yesterday to abstain. The SNP may not have a majority on its own, but the Scottish Greens can always be relied upon to support the nationalists. Even if the report by James Hamilton had concluded that Sturgeon had not only broken the ministerial code but had set fire to it and danced maniacally on its smoking cinders while filming it all on TikTok, she would have won a vote of confidence with the support of her Green friends.But there is no need for another interminable inquiry to add to the three that have only recently been completed. There was the Hamilton report, of course, which found that Sturgeon had indeed given misleading statements to MPs during the inquiry into how the Scottish government handled complaints against the former first minister, Alex Salmond – but she didn’t mean to, so that was alright.Before that there was the report by Laura Dunlop QC into the Scottish Government’s handling of the harassment complaints and how the process could be improved. This concluded that the system adopted by civil servants was flawed because Salmond himself was not allowed to defend himself.And coming in between those two reports were the conclusions of the Holyrood committee set up to investigate how the Scottish Government came to make such a hash of that internal inquiry into the allegations against Salmond. SNP spin doctors, and the First Minister herself, have done a wonderful job in undermining the credibility of this report, drawn up by a cross-section of MSPs from all the parties represented at Holyrood. Its findings, therefore, have drawn less attention than they should have, particularly because the Hamilton report was published on the same day – a helpful, though no doubt entirely coincidental confluence of events.Contrary to what is now received wisdom, the committee report is not only damning of the Scottish Government and its leadership, but most of its conclusions were arrived at via cross-party consensus.The MSPs are particularly critical of Leslie Evans, the chief civil servant in the administration, for the role she played in devising and implementing the initial inquiry into the complaints brought by two women against Salmond after he left office. The committee said it was “astonishing” that no one thought to challenge the appointment of a lead investigating officer who had previously offered support to the two women. This was the key aspect of the inquiry which was successfully challenged by Salmond in court, at a cost of £500,000 to the public purse.It was decisions by Evans’s office that led to delays in handing over key documents that would have exposed this flaw in the internal inquiry – a delay that ratcheted up the cost of the legal fight against Salmond. “This inidual failing is as significant as the general corporate failing,” the MSPs concluded.Sturgeon has spent a good deal of time reasserting her confidence in Evans. How could she not? Given the level of criticism aimed at her, the First Minister would either have to defend her or dismiss her. And the latter course would stick in her craw, partly out of pride but more because losing Evans would look to the outside world like an admission of guilt and a willingness to sacrifice others for her own sake.Sturgeon and her supporters will claim that the fact there have been no resignations is proof that this whole controversy has been about nothing. But the facts disprove such an assertion. The level of incompetence and duplicity by the Scottish Government is clear, indisputable and on the record. But accountability? This is a notion that is apparently unworthy of being applied to nationalist politicians or their incompetent civil servants.This is what happens when any administration is reinforced by an uninterrupted, unassailable polling lead and is guaranteed re-election, whatever it does, however it behaves. SNP partisans might rejoice, but no true democrat can look at what has happened at Holyrood in the last two years and conclude that Scotland is the better for it.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: suez canal blocked ship unable turn around
story: The Suez Canal could be blocked for days after a giant container ship ran aground, snarling up one of the world's busiest maritime trade routes.The MV Ever Given, one of the biggest container ships in operation, blew off course in a sudden gust of wind, authorities said, becoming wedged lengthways across the canal.“The salvage operation with tugs is under way, and hopefully the vessel will be freed soon, but it could last days” as checks are made on the damage to the ship, said Ralph Leszczynski, head of research at shipbroker Banchero Costa &amp Co, told Bloomberg.Suez Canal Authority (SCA) chairman Admiral Osama Rabie said in a statement that rescue and tug units are continuing their efforts to free the MV Ever Given.Aerial photographs showed at least six tugs at work while the SCA has also dispatched excavators to try to dig the ship out from the canal’s bank.The 400-metre long mega-vessel, its deck piled high with upwards of 1,000 shipping containers, has caused a spectacular traffic jam on the narrow, high-volume maritime superhighway.Authorities on Wednesday were attempting to ert the more than 100 ships idling on either side of the narrow canal, both in the Mediterranean off Port Said, and in the north of the Red Sea.As time goes on, experts warn that the ship’s structure could become stressed with so much weight bearing down on the ship’s midsection.If this happens, efforts to dislodge the Ever Given may shift gears to an operation to remove tonnage so she sits up higher in the water.This would mean pumping fuel and unloading containers – no easy feat at such a height and while still at sea.The Taiwan-owned, Panama-flagged MV Ever Given is one of the so-called mega ships that the canal sought to attract when it expanded in 2015 with an aim to reduce waiting times and double the volume of traffic by 2023.The canal has been one of the most reliable drivers of the Egyptian economy in recent years, bringing in $5.61 billion in 2020.Last month, Egyptian president Abdel-Fatah al Sisi ordered his cabinet to adopt a flexible marketing policy for the canal to mitigate the effects of the global economic downturn caused by the pandemic.According to the SCA, nearly 19,000 ships passed through it in 2020, carrying more than one billion tonnes of cargo. Container ships account for more than half of total traffic, with some among the largest in the world.Typically, ships from the Gulf to Europe carry oil, and ships from Europe and North American haul grain and manufactured goods eastwards.Ten per cent of all international trade passes through the canal, which revolutionised global shipping when it first opened in 1869.Today, a ship can halve its journey between ports in the Gulf and London by going through the Suez rather than around the southern tip of Africa.The government of President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi completed a major expansion of the canal in 2015, allowing it to accommodate the world's largest vessels.However, the Ever Given ran aground before that new portion of the canal.The incident Tuesday marks just the latest to affect mariners amid the pandemic. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeCharities helping asylum seekers have blasted the Governmentaposs planned overhaul of the immigration system. Home Secretary Priti Patel vowed to tackle illegal migration head-on as she announced the most signicant overhaul of our asylum system in decades. The “New Plan for Immigration” was comprehensive, fair but firm, she told the Commons. Ms Patel hopes it will stem the flow of migrants making the perilous journey across the English Channel in inflatables. Last year about , reached UK shores, with most claiming asylum. The backlog of cases has hit ,, with , awaiting an initial decision, she told MPs. Ms Patel said: The persistent failure to enforce our immigration rules with a system that is open to gaming by economic migrants and exploitation by criminals is eroding public trust and disadvantaging vulnerable people who need our help. People who arrive in the UK illegally will no longer have the same entitlements as those who arrive legally. The aim is to deter migrants from turning to ruthless smugglers who traffic them to Britain for thousands of pounds. Gangs who organise crossings face le sentences. But Safe Passage International chief executive Beth Gardiner-Smith said: “These proposed reforms will do nothing to prevent dangerous Channel crossings, whilst making the lives of many who have fled war and persecution a misery.” Mike Adamson, chief executive of the British Red Cross said: We agree the asylum system needs reform, but this announcement takes the system backwards not forwards. We should not judge how worthy someone is of asylum by how they arrived here. The proposals effectively create an unfair two-tiered system, whereby someoneaposs case and the support they receive is judged on how they entered the country and not on their need for protection. This is inhumane. Amnesty International UK director Kate Allen said: “For years, Home Office ministers under successive administrations have demonised people who have come to this country to work, study, join family or seek asylum in a blind and unattainable pursuit of control without any semblance of compassion or humanity. “What we really need is for the Home Office to end this harmful pattern which is doing untold damage to people caught up in its systems while increasingly presenting the UK as firmly on the side of abusers, exploiters and oppressors rather than their victims.” The cost of Britainaposs asylum system is expected to rocket by £million this year, from about £m in   to £.bn in  , the plan shows. The blueprint also reveals a consultation will be launched on the “introduction of a new penalty for failure to secure a vehicle, regardless of whether an illegal migrant is found on board or not”. The Home Office moved to quell fears families ing from the Continent could be targeted for leaving a touring caravan door unlocked. A spokesman said: The focus of the enforcement of these measures will be hauliers who do not take appropriate measures to prevent illegal entry into the UK.” Despite claims last week that asylum seekers could be sent to Gibraltar or the Isle of Man while claims are processed, the -page document failed to mention either the Rock or the Crown Dependency.

title: covid must watershed moment britain
story: NewsopinionCovid must be watershed moment for Britain - heres how we fix our broken countryWhen the pandemic is done there is a chance we will forget the suffering of others. My dad Harry Leslie Smith, dubbed the world’s oldest rebel, would have seen yesterday’s day of reflection without definite action as performative politics at its worstmirrorShareCommentsByJohn Smith:,  MAR NewsopinionHarry Leslie Smith addresses the Labour conference in Manchester in  " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeDuring these early footsteps of spring, we long for ato normalcy that has been estranged from us because of Covid . The winter that just passed was harsh and long because our inidual need to be social, to be in public, to interact with others through touch and through close contact were frozen over by the pandemic. After more than  days of on-off lock downs, partial reopening’s and civilian death counts not seen outside of warzones, we long for the familiarity of dinners with friends and family, Friday drinks at the pub, the leisure to watch live sports or attend concerts, with thousands of other enthusiasts. We desire our dance to the music of time to resume, so we can forget the brevity of our encounter with existence. However, society faces a grave danger that it will become trapped into accepting as normal many of the daily inequities the vulnerable, the marginalised and the working poor already encounter in exchange for theof ordinary pleasures. There is a good chance we will forget the suffering of others when our normal activities resume and dismiss the plight of rough sleepers, benefits recipients and refugee applicants as not our concern. It’s why I know my dad Harry Leslie Smith - who because of his advocacy for the vulnerable was called the world’s oldest rebel by the press before he died in  at  - would have been against yesterday’s day of reflection for the dead of Covid . My father learned early in le that national reflection without definite action by our leaders is performative politics at its worst. Late in his le he recalled that as a boy he watched on news reels memorials being erected by councils, all across the country in the s and s, to the fallen of the Great War.  Yet, he bitterly reflected that he encountered during his family’s odyssey of poverty during the Great Depression many of the survivors of the bloody battles at the Somme or Passchendaele living truncated lives in near starvation in doss houses or on the streets. It’s why when he saw David Cameron’s Tory government in  employ austerity to smash away at the Welfare State which his generation had created out of the ashes of the Second World War that he took his last stand against the normalisation of poverty and social inequality. For the next eight years, he fought against xenophobia the politics of hate, austerity as well as economic and social inequality by writing books, doing speaking tours and hosting a podcast.What is your view  Have your say in the comment section His le is an example to us all that an ordinary person can inspire change. You see, before my father became a public figure, he was just a normal pensioner with limited means that liked to winter in Portugal and putter around his garden in Spring. But the circumstances of our times reminded him too much of the era of his youth when the politics of hate turned so rancid that the world plunged itself into war to defeat fascism. My father died in  long before Britain was shuttered by Covid like a high street shop at pm on a Sunday. But he would have seen this pandemic as a watershed moment for Britain and for the world. From coronavirus to Brexit, our daily politics newsletter is there to guide you these turbulent times. The newsletter is sent out twice daily with the latest UK  world politics news, along with leading opinion and analysis.You can sign up here.  My father would have seen this as the time where politics must not only be hopeful but ground-breaking like the Labour politics he embraced, with joy, as a young man at the end of the Second War. That was an era when the Labour party didn’t reflect the times but defined it by rebuilding a Britain to hold and reward the aspirations of the working class rather than the entitled classes. In this time now of reflection when many are still dying from Covid, we must demand of our politicians that they show courage and vision and institute a new Beveridge Report for the st century.

title: heres what can do bristol
story: NewsopinionHeres what you can doyoure angry about the government, without smashing up BristolRiots lose the argument and make the authorities crack down harder, says Fleet Street Fox. Have you tried the alternatives mirrorShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsopinion" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThereaposs nothing more likely to cause a riot than an authoritarian crackdown.And thereaposs nothing more likely to cause an authoritarian crackdown than a riot, which is why those in power are tickled pink that a protest in Bristol about losing the right to protest descended into the kind of violence that saw  police officers hurt and  people arrested.Anger is like white phosphorus - stamping it out just spreads it around. Most of the police realise that, but the government consists of people who are stupid, and populist, which means giving them a riot is like offering Dreamies to the Downing Street cat. Theyaposll bite your arm right off.Every single person who demonstrated peacefully against the new law, which is aimed at curbing proteststhey raise even a risk of noise disturbance or inconvenience, did a grand job, and it was utterly nullied by the far smaller number of people who went out after dark looking for a fight with the bizzies.  Riots almost always happen after dark, because the people that usually start them tend to be nocturnal, and drunk. Any government can survive them. The main reason the poll tax riots of  led to Margaret Thatcheraposs downfall was because they happened in daylight, and sobriety. Thataposs the sort of anger governments cannot ignore.One of the most terrying things I saw while reporting on riots  was in  when a woman of about  in Trafalgar Square set light to a copy of Margaret Thatcheraposs autobiography as a crowd cheered. The refusal to learn, and the urge to destroy, were precisely Thatcheraposs problem, and that young woman had no idea she was doing exactly the same. Burning books spreads ignorance, and sometimes it doesnapost need to go that far.Thinking, on the other hand, is always instructive. And there are several brilliant, far more effective ways of protesting a government whose policies you despise. . Vote in local elections  In just over  weeks time, every adult over the age of  who isnapost in jail will have the right to select local councillors, city mayors, and perhaps most importantly, Police and Crime Commissioners.Only about half of those who vote in general elections bother to express an opinion in local ones. So this one third of law-abiding adults gets to choose, for all of us, how often the roads are resurfaced, where new houses are built, how often the bins are emptied, and whether your elderly mum gets social care visits in her own home.The PCCs are supposed to be the voice of the people, and hold Chief Constables to account. Soyouaposre angry about what the police have been up to, vote for a dferent PCC, rather than kick a cop car. This is only the third time their roles have been up for election, and it was postponed from last May because of the pandemic. If any elected official feels safe in their job, democracy suffers, so go and shake their tree. Not voting is not an option. . Be more Gandhi  In  Mohandas Gandhi led  people on a -day, -mile march to protest the Salt Tax. It was levied by the British government on any Indian who collected or made salt, and produced % of the Rajaposs tax revenue. Gandhi said salt was vital for le, and with a hand-picked band of supporters walked from village to village, making salt as he went. It sparked copycat peaceful protests across the sub-continent, with many women finding their voices for the first time. Soldiers were ordered to open fire on non-violent protesters, but they refused and were jailed instead. Gandhiaposs simple act of civil disobedience provoked a response that could not be stopped. The government was confused by protesters who would not fight, and had no way to tackle them.  Tank Man did more to show up the Chinese government in Tiananmen Square than any other protester. The Berlin Wall was toppled, eventually, by people armed with garden spades and holding candles. And when the peasants revolted in , sacking the Savoy, burning the Temple and breaking open prisons, Richard II had no qualms - and no problems - having Wat Tyler slaughtered and rioters hanged across half of England.One person, doing one peaceful thing, has more power than any army. And think how flummoxed Pratty Patel would be,just one person told her, calmly, that she was wrong. . Spread the word  You might be angry about the Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill. But you have almost certainly not read it, and most people in your family probably have even less of a clue whataposs in it. It not only outlaws a protest by one person with a megaphone on the basis of noise nuisance, but imposes a maximum -year jail sentence for damaging a statue. Whether they would apply that as firmly to an effigy of Emmeline Pankhurst as they would to one of Winston Churchill, who as Home Secretary oversaw violent police crackdowns on suffragettes, no-one yet knows. But it also increases sentences for child murderers, gives more community sentences for less serious crimes, and has measures to tackle sex abusers who work in positions of trust, like teachers or sports coaches. You wonapost win support to kill the bill, when most reasonable people will like bits of it. Which is probably why theyaposve done it.Talk instead about the march from Selma, the Arab Spring, the Womenaposs March, even the pro and anti-Brexit protests. They would all have been illegal under this law, along with suffragettes chaining themselves to railings, or the Jarrow Marchers who just wanted a job.One of the most dystopian clauses is that a person commits a crimethey do not follow rules they have not been told about. Tell people about that, and then ask themthey know what all the rules are.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeLiverpool council could be partly run from Whitehall, following a “deeply concerning” report into alleged corruption. Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick said the review “paints a deeply concerning picture of mismanagement, breakdown of scrutiny and accountability. Telling MPs the report had found multiple apparent failures by the City Council - he announced commissioners would be sent in to run “limited s” of the authority for three years.The authority, a Labour stronghold, and its councillors will have some of their s taken over by the Ministry for Housing, Communities and Local Governmentfor its day-to-day operations, through Government-appointed commissioners.And Mr Jenrick outlined an “improvement plan” city leaders will be expected to follow. The council will have  days to make representations on the proposals. Inspectors were sent in to the council in December following the arrests of five men, including elected mayor Joe Anderson, who was held on suspicion of conspiracy to commit bribery and witness intimidation. The councilaposs director of regeneration, Nick Kavanagh, was also arrested as part of the police probe into building and development contracts in the city, and this week it was confirmed he had been dismissed from his role at the authority. In a statement to the Liverpool Echo, he said he intended to clear his name at a tribunal. Mr Anderson, , has also denied any wrongdoing. Merseyside Police said all suspects remain under investigation but bail has not been extended. Mr Jenrick said: This package is centred on putting in place commissioners who I will appoint to exercise certain and limited s of the council as required for a minimum of three years.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeNew coronavirus laws, including an explicit ban on foreign holidays, have been laid before Parliament. MPs will vote on the legislation on Thursday to underpin Boris Johnsonaposs roadmap out of lockdown and pave the way for ongoing restrictions to our daily lives. The national lockdown expires on March  and the new legislation is designed to enshrine the Prime Ministeraposs four-step lockdown exit plan in law. But the Government is facing concern from Tory backbenchers over being asked to extend some lockdown powers until October - despite plans for ato normality in June. While the legislation is expected to pass on Thursday with Labouraposs backing, the PM will be braced for anger from his own MPs about the continuation of tough restrictions amid positive signs over the impact the vaccine rollout. The new laws do not mean that the roadmap out of lockdown is changing. They give the Government the legal powers to enact the four-step plan which Mr Johnson has already set out. Hereaposs what the legislation says and what it means.Why is the law changing New regulations will effectively override the old tier system, which still forms the basis of the laws behind lockdown.Known as the Health Protection Coronavirus, Restrictions Regulations , the rules will replace tiers with a series of steps based on the proposed dates of the PMaposs roadmap out of lockdown for England.The change is needed now because lockdown ends in law on March , so something is needed to replace it. The new legislation expires on June . Separately, MPs will also be asked to renew the emergency powers in the Coronavirus Act, which covers support packages like furlough and business loan schemes, as well as allowing courts to use video technology. MPs must vote to extend these powers every six months, meaning the next vote could be in October. Does it mean lockdown will last until October No. The Government says it wants to keep the Coronavirus Act in place for now to ensure it can respond to pandemic effectively. This does not affect the Prime Ministeraposs plan to ease lockdown measures. However Tory MPs have expressed concern that the sweeping powers could remain in place so long after lockdown is supposed to have ended. The separate roadmap regulations end on June , in line with the Governmentaposs plan to ease restrictions after June . That is the expiry date for the legislation but the Government can scrap or amend itnecessary. The restrictions must be reviewed by April  and at least once every  days afterwards. Mr Johnson has repeatedly said he wants the lting of measures to be irreversible - hence the cautious attitude to unlocking. The Government doesnapost want to be in a situation like after the second lockdown in November when strict measures had to be reimposed again quickly due to a spike in cases.  Is there anything new in the legislation  Most of the fine print matches up with the Prime Ministeraposs roadmap out of lockdown . One eye-catching element was a ban on foreign holidays, with £, fines for anyone who breaks the rules. There is also a £ fixed penalty notice for failing to fill in a travel declaration form to explain your reasons for going abroad. The travel ban does not apply to those going to the Channel Islands, Isle of Man and the Republic of Ireland - unless that is not the final destination. So you canapost travel to Dublin to catch a flight from there. Exemptions also apply including for those needing to travel for work, study, for legal obligations or to vote,they are moving, selling or renting property, for some childcare reasons or to be present at a birth, to visit a dying relative or close friend, to attend a funeral, for those getting married or to attend the wedding of a close relative, for medical appointments or to escape a risk of harm. At present, this is due to last until the restrictions expire on June  but the Government could speed that up when it considers a review of foreign travel next month. Protests will be allowed again as an exemption to rules banning group gatherings. They must be organised by a business, public or political body or other group and organisers must take the required precautions, which is likely to include measures like ensuring people wear face masks and are socially distanced.  So what is the timetable for lting lockdown  England’s restrictions will ease in four stages, startingon March , April , May  and June . Step  began on March , with the reopening of schools and a slight easing of restrictions to let people meet one other person outside for a coffee or a picnic. The second part of Step  is due on March , which will allow up to six people to meet outdoors but restricts indoor gatherings of two or more people. Some outdoor sports are permitted, and open air facilities like swimming pools and tennis courts can reopen.  The stay-at-home order will end. People will be asked to stay local but it wonapost be compulsory. You will be allowed to leave home for non-essential reasons and use public transport. Step , which could come into effect from April , is when non-essential shops can reopen as well as hairdressers, gyms, zoos, theme parks and libraries. Pubs and other hospitality venues will be able to serve customers outside - but rules around social contact remain in place, so rule of six or two households. Professor Adam Finn, who sits on the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation , insisted that no decision has been made about vaccinating children - despite reports youngsters could start receiving the jab as early as August. The University of Bristol expert said more research was needed before the JCVI could decidethe vaccination programme should be extended to cover children and young people. Under-s are currently not eligible for the Covid jab in most cases but Oxford University is researching the effects of the jab on children, with early results expected in the summer. Children rarely fall ill with the virus but they do play a role in its transmission. While children are unlikely to fall ill with Covid-, they do play a role in transmitting the virus. Officials are said to be looking at how the jab could be extended to children, with the potential to start as early as August, thereported. Asked about the reports, Prof Finn told Good Morning Britain: As far as I know there has been no decision made to immunise children starting in August, or indeed any decision been taken to immunise children at all at this point. But itaposs certainly something that we might need to do. Prof Finn said it was likely that teenagers would be prioritised as the existing evidence shows older children were more likely to spread the virus. He said results from more than one study are needed, adding: If it does turn out to be necessary to immunise children, I think it is more likely that we would prioritise teenagers over younger children, simply because the evidence we have at the moment is that transmission of the virus is more likely to occur from and between teenagers who are a little bit more like adults. I think what we need to learn before thatwhat proportion of the population we need to immunise in order to get effective herd immunity and to suppress circulation of the virus.

Her mother was a heroin addict and the baby was discharged into the care of her grandmother. Another woman was appointed the girl’s specialand on July  Lilly moved into the woman’s house. Lilly was doing extremely well until the woman began a relationship with Saddler in Spring . He became a regular visitor and she began to leave Lilly in Sadler’s care with devastating consequences. Today at Birmingham Crown Court, Sadler, of Northfield, was found guilty of murder and wounding with intent following a trial, ending a three-year wait for justice for Lillyaposs family.  On November , , Lilly was rushed to Birmingham Children’s Hospital after she was found unresponsive at her home. She died three days later. The court heard the tot had been a normal, healthy girl. Jonas Hankin QC, prosecuting, said: She had no recent signicant illness or accident. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA teenager Snapchatted his friends saying goodbye everyone before he killed himself, an inquest heard. Kian Southway died on March  last year just over a week after the first national lockdown began.The talented kickboxer had worries about not being able to sit exams and about a relationship, an inquest at Pontypridd Coronersapos Court heard, Wales Online reports.Four days before he died the Treorchy -year-old had asked his father what time he was going to bed at around .pm. At around .am his younger sister Darcey received a phone call from a concerned friend saying Kian had put up a Snapchat message saying goodbye everyone and she rushed to tell her parents. Kian was found by his parents at their home and the emergency services were alerted. The family did all they could to try and save him before he was taken to hospital in Cardf. The Ysgol Gyfun Cwm Rhondda pupil was known as a polite and considerate boy. Some of Kianaposs friends provided statements to the coroner and explained he had recently been upset about a relationship he had been involved in with a girl. One friend, who had recently spoken to Kian on Snapchat prior to the incident, said: At first Kian and I were just talking about normal stuff and he askedhe could tell me something. I told Kian he could tell me anything. He chatted about a girl. I didnapost really know what to say to him. Kian didnapost mention anything to me that made me think he would try and harm himself. It was around pm to .pm. That was the last conversation I had with him. The last message I had was a picture message on Snapchat saying aposgoodbye everyoneapos. I didnapost see the message until about am. The girl Kian had been seeing more of leading up to his death also provided a statement to the coroner. She said they werenapost in a relationship but described them as being more than just friends. They had known each other since being in year six but became closer after spending time together at a house party prior to lockdown. The hearing was told Kian became upset when the pair started to talk less.  Her statement read: I last saw Kian the weekend prior to his death. We had a bit of a tf but I wouldnapost say it was a fight or an argument. I wouldnapost always reply straightaway to Kianaposs messages but I didnapost reply to anyone aposs either. I found out what had happened on March . I was forwarded a Snapchat story. The inquest was told Kian spoke to another friend on March  where he expressed being a bit down but said he would be in a happier place tomorrow. It was thought at the time he just meant tomorrow would be a better day as everything was normal. The inquest was told while at hospital Kian spent time in the care of Dr Michelle Jardine, a consultant in paediatric intensive care at the University Hospital of Wales. The staff did all they could to help Kian but, as time went on, it became clear a large part of his brain had been affected by the incident. His condition declined within the last  hours of his le and he died on March , . A statement read on behalf of Kianaposs mother, Jolene Southway, explained the family thought the incident may have been a cry for help but they couldnapost get there soon enough to save him.  Ms Southway mentioned in her statement that Kian once listened to a talk about a woman who contemplated suicide in the Brecon Beacons but someone saved her. When the family once went to Pen y Fan Kian wanted Ms Southway to take him to this area. In the statement she said: Kian wanted me to take him to where the lady spoke about. It was strange how Kian had wanted to visit the area where the woman had wanted to end her le. A statement read on behalf of Ms Southway read: Kian was bright, he was popular, and he was a joy to teach. He loved school and he loved being out with the boys. He always had A*s and As but when he got results he did get some Bs. We probably did give him a little bit of a hard time. The inquest was told he missed school during lockdown and worried about not being able to sit exams and having to rely on predicted grades. Ms Southwayaposs statement also explained the family wasnapost aware Kian had been involved with a girl until more recently. She said when they asked him where he was going before the pandemic Kian simply replied: Out. The statement added: Which was odd because he always told us where he was going. He text us saying he was at a girlaposs house. Ms Southway said he had also become more body conscious. The family reminded Kian that the girl he had been messaging was also experiencing lockdown and may need some time. Kian was said to respond: This is the reason I didnapost want a girlfriend. The statement read on behalf of Ms Southway continued: When he broke up with his first girlfriend he was crying in his room and she said: aposDonapost be silly – there are plenty more fish in the seaapos. The hearing was told Kian registered as an organ donor because he had said in the past: If anything happens to me there is no point in my organs going with me. Two adult lives have since been saved as a result of Kian being a donor. The medical cause of death was provided as a global hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy and hanging.

Elleanor Holland was alerted to a white envelop left outside the front door of her home in Barnoldswick, Lancashire, when it was spotted by a neighbour on Saturday morning. The -year-old insists she has no idea who would leave her such a bizarre declaration of love, but says she expects it may be a apostown bachelorapos on the hunt for love. Her partner, -year-old Adam Greenway, has thankfully not felt threatened by the bold attempt to steal his girlfriend, and Elleanor has said that the gt has left them in fits of laughter rather than feeling uneasy.
