Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Crowds gather to say farewell to HMS CampbeltownPeople gathered on Campbeltown#s promenade to say farewell to its namesake ship as she fired an -gun salute to mark her visit.HMS Campbeltown left the town for the last time on Monday morning and she carried out the salute with the ship#s company lining its decks.A six Verey pistol salute from Dalintober Quay, a lone piper at Campbeltown New Quay and locals to see her off, all packed the front of the town.The type- frigate is due to be decommissioned in Plymouth in April.During her time here, the ship#s company went ashore to take in the best on offer in Campbeltown, such as surfing, golf and clay pigeon shooting.She heads for St Nazaire in France on March  and then heads for Devonport for her decommissioning on April .TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOChildren#s paddling pool is filled inArgyll and Bute District Council plans to bulldoze the crazy golf course and trampolines at Kilkerran Green within the next few weeks.The paddling pool at the Quarry Green children#s play park is being filled as part of the major renovation of the children#s public play area.The council decided to dismantle the crazy golf and trampoline area and replace them with a £, #galleon# style climbing frame with safety surface.A council spokeswoman said a putting green was also being considered for the site.The paddling pool is being filled in after it was learned that it would cost £, to re-line to prevent leaks.The safety of youngsters using the pool was also causing concerns.District councillor Mr Archie McCallum said: #There have been growing complaints about the amount of broken glass being thrown into the pool during summer months.#FIFTY YEARS AGOCod’s truthMany strange things have been dragged up in fishing nets, but a find last week by a Campbeltown fisherman beats all we have ever heard about.Mr William Colville, of Davaar Avenue, is a crewman aboard the local boat Kirsteen Anne . While he was gutting and cleaning a large cod at sea, something fell onto the deck.When the deck was cleared and washed down, Mr Colville examined his find# the honeycomb from a bee#s hive!How on earth it ever managed to find its way to the murky depths and into a cod#s stomach we will never discover.It is just #one of those things#.Councillors call for removal of #eyesore#Campbeltown councillors are up in arms about a #rusting eyesore# which is lying on the shores of Campbeltown Loch.The ex-Admiralty tug Empire Ace ran aground at Southend nearly two years ago and was towed to the loch, where it was beached. It has lain at the Rocky Burn area ever since.The vessel caused a row between the Town Council and the firm who owned it, George Hood and Company of Helensburgh.At a meeting last September, it was suggested that the firm be charged dues.Councillor Harry Moffat was quoted as saying: #If people are allowed to dump boats in the loch, I can go and dump a car and nobody can do anything about it.#The council discussed the question of taking legal action against the firm. A considerable number of people have since remarked on the unsightliness of the vessel, which has started to rust.Fishermen ing from the grounds were using the Empire Ace as a mooring stage while they cleaned and washed their catches.But a spokesman for the Helensburgh firm said that it had sold the vessel some months ago. The spokesman refused to reveal the identity of the buyers, but after inquiries, we ascertained that it was purchased by McFadyen’s, the local contracting firm.A spokesman for Archibald McFadyen and Sons said that the Empire Ace was purchased by the firm about two weeks ago.He added that breaking up work was to start on the vessel #within the next few days#.Tobacco firm expands furtherThe well-known Campbeltown firm of Richard Daniels Ltd, tobacco wholesalers and distributors, has opened a depot in Peebles, to meet an increased demand from customers on the east coast.The firm, whose custom stretches from Aberdeen to Middlesborough in England, has just been awarded a #very large# contract from a brewing firm to supply its retail outlet # public houses.Askedthe Peebles opening would create redundancies locally, Mr James Daniels told the Courier that staff in Campbeltown would be unaffected.#It is merely a new phase being added to the business,# he said.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOCastlehill Church Sunday SchoolThe children of the Kinloch Church Sunday School had a highly enjoyable social evening on Friday last. After the customary tea, brief addresses of a helpful nature were given by Rev N Mackenzie, Mr Drysdale , Mr Dick, Mr M’Dougall, Mrs M’Kerrow and the chairman, Rev CVA MacEachran.Among the singers were Misses M’Naughton, M’Cloy, Black and Burnfield, and among the reciters Misses M’Naughton, Macdonald, and Gilchrist, and John M’Lachlan and Don Gilchrist.The two most juvenile performers were amongst the best # Nancy Noal and Norman Keith.A sketch carrying a good moral was cleverly presented as well as a duet in character by J Black and Babette Burnfield. During the evening, Mrs Keith, Gowanlea, presented about  certicates from the Church of Scotland for perfect attendance throughout the year, and  for regular attendance.The musical programme reflected much credit upon Miss Finlay and Mr Hogg who trained the children and upon Miss Rae who was accompanist.

title: letters march 19 2021
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  At the start of the pandemic in March we took the decision to make online access to our news free of charge by taking down our paywall. At a time where accurate information about Covid- was vital to our community, this was the right decision # even though it meant a drop in our income. In order to help safeguard the future of our journalism, the time has now come to reinstate our paywall.However, rest assured that access to all Covid related news will still remain free.To access all other news will require a subscription, as it did pre-pandemic.The good news is that for the whole of December we will be running a special discounted offer to get  months access for the price of one month. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.With regard to Mr Wilson#s letter, entitled #mishmash of worn out tropes#, published in the March  edition of the Courier, my initial reaction was not to conduct a political diatribe within the pages of the local paper my thoughts were that I would let others decide whose letter is more appropriate.However, on reflection, I decided to reply to the comments relating to my vaccine observations in which he states that for me #to denigrate the EU vaccine programme is crass and over simplistic#, followed by #our success is an illusion until both doses are administered#, and therefore I am accused of not only #crowing about vaccines# but of being presumptuous and inappropriate.Mr Wilson has a total misunderstanding of who I am and what my beliefs are. I care about mankind in general and the plight of its citizens, particularly where there is a prevalence of political ineptitude affecting their lives.To reiterate, the EU purchasing system regarding vaccines was and still is chaotic, with the bureaucratic executive in Brussels initially lashing out, and currently certain members within the group are endeavouring to purchase supplies of vaccines for their citizens.In addition, we now have a ban by some countries of vaccine exports from EU manufacturers to non-EU countries. An action which has angered the World Health Organization and upset Australia and other countries.Regarding the comment that the vaccine success is an illusion, perhaps the perusal of some scientic pronouncements in relation to the efficacy would be appropriate.To accuse me of crowing is not only resented but additionally hurtful. I have an extended family in France.My daughter is married to a now retired French army captain and she is an environmental scientist and director of a laboratory in the IRD , a French public research institution. While her mother-in-law has had her first vaccination and in the last week so has her husband, she does not know when she will get an appointment.Currently, in certain areas of France, the virus is very active and part of her remit involves travel to some of these hot-spots when working from home is not practicable. A situation which is very concerning to me.I also do not know when I will be permitted to see them, either in France or in Scotland.Crowing, indeed, I think not.Amidst the miscellany of economic disaster claims awaiting an independent Scotland thrown up by Michael McGeachy in last week#s Courier, I am gratied that Mr McGeachy does, at the very least, accept that Scotland has no debt at the point of independence. This is progress.Unfortunately, Mr McGeachy then goes on to hold up Scotland#s putative deficit as an ace card in the unionist case to #prove# that Scotland is an economic basket-case surviving on English largesse. In reality, it demonstrates the opposite.Scotland#s #deficit#, created within the UK, with our overall budget set by another government # that#s  per cent of Scotland#s revenues and  per cent of our spending # is a damning indictment of Westminster#s reckless economic vandalism. It is the cost of Westminster Tory rule and the union#s failure.Indeed,being part of the UK was such an advantage, Scotland would have a stronger economy than our northern independent competitors.That they are all considerably more successful, with fewer economic resources than Scotland, makes the case for Scotland to have control of all the sovereign economic levers required to succeed in the global economy.Mr McGeachy concludes with the familiar splenetic, #you had your referendum# in . In this time we have had three Prime Ministers, two Westminster elections and one Holyrood election, not forgetting England#s Brexit imposed upon Scotland.Democracy is not pick and mix, Mr McGeachy. The #Better Together# parties can huff and puff about #taking back control# to London, but Scotland is not their possession.We still live in a free country andScots vote this May for an SNP government focused on Scottish priorities, including the right to ensure that Scotland#s future is Scotland#s choice, not Boris Johnson#s, democracy, as we saw with the election of President Biden, will prevail.The fact that the SNP has produced a new digital strategy document will come as little consolation to residents of the Highlands and Islands, who would struggle to download it eventhey wanted to.The SNP has left the Highlands and Islands in the digital dark ages.The  SNP manesto committed to deliver superfast broadbandto every home and business by . This has comprehensively failed, with ministers refusing to discuss completion dates. A December  report logged an average download speed of .Mbps in Glen Shiel. That is  times slower than Scotland’s fastest street.The pandemic has exposed the glaring digital ide that exists between rural and urban parts of Scotland.Scottish Liberal Democrats want our remote and rural communities to be great places to live, work and study.That#s why we are setting out new proposals to put power in the hands of local community managers and prioritise investment in catch-up zones to ensure that everyone has access to the digital services they need to prosper.Cancer continues to claim lives regardless of the pandemic.As resources within the NHS are stretched to their limits, charities like Target Oian Cancer need your help more than ever before. Please help us raise awareness and raise funds. Whilst we are all fighting coronavirus, Target Oian Cancer is putting the needs of women with oian cancer before all .In , my mother, the actress Marjie Lawrence, was diagnosed with oian cancer just three weeks before she died.Had we and her doctors been aware of the symptoms, Marjie might be alive today. If diagnosed at the earliest stage, nine in  women will survive. But two thirds of women are diagnosed late, when the cancer is harder to treat.This March, for Oian Cancer Awareness Month, I#m writing to ask your readers to take just two minutes of their time to learn the symptoms and spread the word to their families and friends.The main symptoms of oian cancer are: persistent bloating, feeling full or having dficulty eating, tummy pain, and needing to wee more often or more urgently.If you believe in a future where every woman diagnosed with oian cancer has the best chance of survival, please show your support and visit www.targetoiancancer.org.uk March

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.On December  , the world stood aghast as the historic building and some of the club#s prized possessions and memorabilia were completely destroyed by fire.The keys for the new building, designed by G Architects and built by Kintyre firm McKinven and Colville, which stands on the same site, were officially handed over to the club on Monday.As well as offering a range of state-of-the-art facilities to golfers and non-golfers, the clubhouse offers hope and a bright future to the community in the form of several new jobs # many of which have already been filled # and a vibrant visitor attraction.It also provides an opportunity, once Covid restrictions are lted, for the club to bounce back in the most spectacular fashion from the devastation of the fire and the impact of Covid- on golf and the club in general.The clubhouse has been designed with spectacular views at its core # there are panoramic views through the tall glass window frontage upstairs, where members and visitors can enjoy the modern bar and catering facilities overlooking the famous first tee down below.Downstairs is the working hub of the club # home of the official administrative area and committee meeting room the trophy cabinet filled with historic trophies rescued by staff and members before the  fire took hold the club champions# boards and the gents#, ladies# and junior locker rooms # for the first time all under the one roof.The jewel in the crown is undoubtedly the new £, swing room on the ground floor.It is fitted with the latest TrackMan technology to trace ball flight and swing speed statistics.This can be used as an indoor practise area for members, by the golf club professional to take inidual coaching sessions, or to take group coaching of the club#s junior golfers. It also offers golfers a virtual golf simulator where they will be able to play some of the best courses in the world.In line with the focus on reducing the club#s carbon footprint and the ambition to become more environmentally friendly, the new clubhouse boasts the latest air source heating technology providing the most efficient renewable heating.Aligned to this bright future, the number of junior members at the golf club continues to boom despite the recent lack of clubhouse facilities # there are now  members under the age of , making up  per cent of the total membership.Club captain William Livingston said: #This truly is a momentous moment in the club#s history. The design by G Architects has always stimulated the imagination and it coming to le has been truly inspiring.#The club would like to thank Roy Malcolm and the design team at G Architects for delivering this outstanding building.#The skill and workmanship of Barry Colville and his team in building this magnicent asset has been outstanding, particularly with all of the challenges laid out on a construction site during the global pandemic.#They have worked tirelessly to bring the project to completion in such a short timescale and we want to pass on our sincere gratitude to them for the wonderful job they have done.#I#d like to thank the club#s staff and the committee who, over the last two years, have worked incredibly hard to support the project over and above undertaking their normal club duties.#The club looks forward to welcoming all members, visitors and guests alike to share in this wonderful new facility just as soon as the Scottish Government advises us that it is safe to do so.#Barry Colville, managing director of McKinven and Colville Ltd, said: #Firstly, I#d like to express how incredibly proud I am of both our staff team and our sub-contractors for providing the endless expertise, dedication and commitment they have shown in bringing this magnicent project from design to completion.#This is particularly rewarding for us as a company, especially to do so within the challenging times that we have all had to encounter over the past year.#I#d also like to thank the project#s design team, Roy and the rest of the G staff team, for their spectacular design and support throughout the project.#Finally, I#d like to thank the Machrihanish Golf Club committee for having the faith in awarding this contract to McKinven and Colville Ltd.#We very much look forward to the club opening its doors to all the members in the near future, allowing us all to enjoy this new, st century building, which I believe, will be an envy of many golf clubs throughout the country.#

title: thought for the week march 19 2021
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  At the start of the pandemic in March we took the decision to make online access to our news free of charge by taking down our paywall. At a time where accurate information about Covid- was vital to our community, this was the right decision # even though it meant a drop in our income. In order to help safeguard the future of our journalism, the time has now come to reinstate our paywall.However, rest assured that access to all Covid related news will still remain free.To access all other news will require a subscription, as it did pre-pandemic.The good news is that for the whole of December we will be running a special discounted offer to get  months access for the price of one month. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Double standards  We face them again and again.A teacher corrects a child for doing something the teacher has also done. A boss criticises a worker for an unavoidable error. A law officer takes a bribe. A cashier short changes a customer…I could go on.Danish philosopher Soren Kierkegaard remained a Christian all his le, but was very critical of the church in his day for its double standards.As we approach Easter, I think of how the crowds who welcomed Jesus into Jerusalem, pulling branches off the trees to wave, shouting #Hosanna# so enthusiastically, were largely the same crowds calling for his blood only days later when they called #Crucy#. How could they turn so quickly  Where was their integrity Some just followed the crowd others feared Jesus was challenging the accepted order, so better get rid of him for the greater good.If we face betrayal, injustice, double standards, how do we react  Revenge, get our own back  That is a very natural reaction, but the consequence is to prolong the bitterness, perhaps ramp up the situation.Jesus asks us to step back, to #turn the other cheek# , to suck up the injustice, the double standards, and let peace rule.Impossible  Well, that is what He did at the cross, and because of Him, I think it is possible.I don#t always get it right in my le, but #don#t do as I do , do as He tells you#. In the long run, it is for your own good.

title: musselburgh-residents-face-weeks-disruption-eskview-terrace-close
story: Eskview Terrace will shut northbound for about five weeks from Monday, with vehicles having to find another way into town.And a local councillor is urging residents to continue to support businesses in the Eskview area during the y closure.Councillor John Williamson fears that the closure will have ldquoa severe effect on businesses, such as takeaways, a bakery and two general stores newsagents on Eskview Terrace and Stoneybank Terrace. He appealed to the public to support the businesses ldquoas far as possible.Mr Williamson said: ldquoIf you usually use these shops, please continue to try to do so, evenit causes you a bit of inconvenience.ldquoFor example, you might have to park your car a bit further away or walk instead of driving.ldquoThe work being done is essential replacement of gas mains and the whole road will not be dug up ndash there will be works in certain places, with new pipework passed through the old pipework to the next joint.ldquoThis is happening in ious parts of the local area with a programme of rolling road closures.Bus services will also be erted, with a spokesperson for Lothian Buses saying: ldquoDue to the closure of Eskview Terrace in one direction, buses on service  and N will operate via Clayknowes Crescent as far as the roundabout by Musselburgh Railway Station. They will then come back upon themselves and operate via Newhailes Road when heading towards Musselburgh only. Journeys towards Edinburgh will be unaffected.Eskview Terrace was closed for three days last week for emergency work but an SGN spokesperson said this took less time than expected and the road was reopened both ways to traffic however, it will close again on Monday for further network improvements.She said: ldquoOur gas network upgrade work will begin on Monday, March , as previously planned.ldquoAll affected customers and businesses in the area have been sent a letter confirming all of the project details for the start date of March .ldquoEskview Terrace will be closed for five weeks from Monday, March , and local road closures will also be in place at times on both Eskview Crescent and Eskview Road. Residents will be notied of these dates.ldquoOur project manager is working to visit each affected business inidually to make sure deliveries are unimpacted and that our work causes minimal disruption to them.In a letter to councillors, the company stated: ldquoTo ensure everyonersquos safety around our work area, wersquore installing two-way temporary traffic lights with pedestrian phase at its junction with Olivebank Road and Eskview Terrace.ldquoWe need to carry out safety-critical work to upgrade the gas network in your area.ldquoThis needs to go ahead now, rather than wait until the pandemic passes, to ensure your local community continues to receive a safe and reliable gas supply.ldquoThe project will be carried out by our contractor George Ritchie, Utilities, on our behalf and will last approximately  weeks.ldquoFor everyonersquos continued safety, the road lane closure, temporary traffic lights and local ersions will be in place. Emergency vehicle access will be maintained at all times.ldquoDuring this project, we will be required to close Eskview Terrace northbound between Stoneybank Terrace and Olivebank Road ndash this will be in place for approximately five weeks.ldquoA local ersion route will be in place during this time.ldquoSome residential streets will also be closed however, access will be maintained via signed ersion routes.ldquoThe suspension of parking will also be required throughout works.ldquoTo minimise disruption, our work will be carried out on a phased basis.ldquoAccess to driveways will always be maintained where possible. Should this change, we will speak with the occupier prior.ldquoWe wish to assure you that work will progress as quickly as possible and wersquoll be doing everything we can to limit delays and disruption during our project.ldquoWe have extra safety precautions in place to protect our colleagues and our communities from the virus.ldquoOur colleagues will be keeping to social distancing guidelines on our sites and wersquod ask communities to keep their distance too.ldquoWersquore writing to residents and other local stakeholders to make them aware of our project and explain the details of our work.ldquoIf you have any specic enquiries about this project, please call us on    and our customer service team will be happy to help.

title: mixed-toilets-considered-musselburgh-grammar-school-refurbishment
story: The plan is part of a project, launched in , to redevelop social and dining spaces to take account of the increasing school roll.An external agency, Architecture + Design Scotland, has consulted with pupils on their priorities for the refurbishment.Students were keen that the lack of social space and conditions of the toilets were addressed.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said that consultation has been at the heart of the project since the start, with ldquoextensive discussions at each stage with both the parent and pupil councils.This has included discussion on the redevelopment and reconfiguration of the space, range of furniture in the social space, and the specication of the toilets.She said that the size of the dining and social area would be almost doubled following the refurbishment.The revamped space will benefit from a new ceiling, lighting, decoration and flooring. Large screens and improved wi-fi will be installed, along with new furniture creating a ldquoversatile space for dining, socialising and learning, with options of informal teaching or group working.During the  consultation, pupils wanted to develop the idea of non-designated toilets that were open to all.Three signage options are being considered:The council spokesperson said the cubicles were fully enclosed from floor to ceiling, offering complete privacy.They followed the design in use in the Dunbar Grammar School extension and Wallyford Primary School, as well as many other schools and public buildings across Scotland.Following consultation with the parent and pupil council, four separate cubicles have also been designed with wash hand basins within, offering an additional choice of facilities.The council spokesperson said: ldquoMusselburgh Grammar students are being asked for their views. Signage,chosen, would be erected at the entrance to the toilets as it would be at any other toilet block.The current pupil council is aware that the initial consultation was three years ago and is looking to revisit the designation of toilets to give new pupil cohorts the opportunity to share views.Pupils are being asked to vote in confidence on the available signage options for the new toilets using a Google form.The spokesperson said: ldquoThe refurbishment programme at Musselburgh Grammar will offer a more modern and spacious social and dining area that will also support learning. New toilet facilities will be part of the space.ldquoThe proposals have been developed following extensive consultation with the parent and pupil councils and we continue to work closely with both groups.ldquoAll cubicles within the two toilet blocks are floor to ceiling and private. When the doors are closed, it looks like a wall. There is a universal sink. At the end of each block there are additional toilets which contain private sinks. There are additional toilet options throughout the school.ldquoWe already have examples of similar set-ups within some other school buildings and there are examples of this design in schools across Scotland. When the consultation has concluded, an equalities impact assessment will be completed.ldquoWe are committed to the principles of equality and inclusion in line with the Equalities Act .Gaynor Allen and Andrew Horrell, co-chairs of the parent council, said: ldquoThe parent council is delighted that the proposed refurbishment is due to take place soon ndash it gives our young people far more social space and really modernises the ground floor of the school. The Pupil Voice team, working with representatives of East Lothian Council, plan to conduct a survey of pupils to determine the operational arrangements for the toilet facilities. The parent council has asked for this survey to be extended to parents.ldquoThe refurbishment and new toilet block have been discussed atat parent council meetings and most parent council members are happy to go along with the wishes of our young people.ldquoEast Lothian Council oversee the statutory and legal requirements for these developments.

title: lockdown-chronicled-new-online-digital-art-exhibition
story: Gran Olivia Begbie ndash whose image lsquoHands On Windows ndash Grandmother and Granddaughterrsquofeatures in the lsquoStories of Covidrsquo exhibition ndash ended up celebrating her th birthday on campus with a bacon roll at Maggiersquos, the Studentsrsquo Union cafe.Jim McRobert, who, along with his partner, is ldquoan invaluable member and supporter of the QMU allotment community, wrote a poem about lockdown which is also part of the exhibition.Olivia said: ldquoThe memories of my birthday breakfast at Maggiersquos will always stay with me, because the staff made it extra special.ldquoThere were balloons on the table and a card. Then they came, with their masks on, and sang Happy Birthday, before presenting me with a chocolate cake.ldquoIf I had been at The Ritz in London I couldnrsquot have had a better birthday celebration than I did that day.Jim got involved with the university allotment last spring, when Scottish Government guidance was clear about allotment spaces following Covid- restrictions.He explained: ldquoI am one of the many regulars that walk the grounds of the university as I live approximately  minutes away. He added: ldquoNot many weeks into the Covid crisis, I was walking past the allotment and asked the two lecturersI could be of assistance. They were hoping to box in the vegetable plots and I was delighted to be able to help.ldquoRegular involvement in this project probably did wonders for my mental health during the almost continual lockdowns.Amidst the pandemic, Queen Margaret University was still catering for students living on campus but its catering outlet, run by BaxterStorey, also became the ldquogo-to place for the local community.Dr Kath MacDonald, honorary lecturer in nursing and director of ListenUpStorytelling, led the latest project, and Courtney Bates and Jasmin Geissen, who are studying for an MA in arts, festival and cultural management, created the online exhibition.Dr MacDonald explained: ldquoAs peoplersquos normal routines were disrupted, they began exploring dferent options.ldquoOne local Musselburgh resident was encouraged to get involved in the university allotment.ldquoAnother went on to enjoy an alternative birthday celebration at a sun-drenched picnic table in University Square ndash marking her birthday with a bacon roll in the company of staff from the university and BaxterStorey.ldquoIt is stories like this that are part of the exhibition and it is heartening to see how good things can often come out of bad situations.Principal Sir Paul Grice said: ldquoIt has been a privilege to be part of this projectrsquos steering group, which essentially acts as an archive collection, documenting one of the most challenging years in the universityrsquos history.ldquoIt tells a collective story of the university, made up of inidual moments and tales which will resonate with many.The exhibition can be accessed at artsteps view ddcebdf

title: young-children-find-creative-ways-support-leuchie-house-home
story: All were raising money for Leuchie House respite centre, found on the outskirts of North Berwick.Harris Gordon attended the North Berwick school hub, where he planned and designed a shop which story: July FINN took his daughter Eilidh by the hand as he walked under the trees towards the river.Twenty-six years had passed since he was last here ndash a memory he had locked away with so many others.They walked past a prehistoric broch which Finn couldnrsquot remember seeing last time. His aunt would have surely pointed it out to him. Then he read the information board and realised it was a recent reconstruction. The name of the nearby cafe now made sense to him.On the path that followed the old railway line, Finn stopped. There it was, hersquod found it: the oak tree. It still looked young, standing guard over the pebbly beach with multiple spreading branches and the magisterial presence Finn remembered.His daughter headed immediately to the waterrsquos edge. It was a much busier place now, with frequent walkers on the nearby path.There was a suspension footbridge spanning the river which Finn couldnrsquot recall. A couple walking by paused for a moment but didnrsquot come to the beach. Perhaps social distancing had some benefits, thought Finn.While his daughter played, he tried to identy the spot he had spent that first night of storytelling with his aunt.ldquoHere, right here, he whispered to himself.Time and space fused together as he imagined going back to the past to explain to his -year-old self what that evening of tales around the fire had really meant.But he would not have been able to listen, not even to his older self. His world then was a broken mirror with vital pieces missing in which he could see only part of himself those pieces lost to him forever. Guilt and anger clawed at Finnrsquos gut, rousing his depression from its slumber.He felt the dark creature trying to pull him down, pain taking over. No, not now, he thought, not in the presence of his daughter.He would not submit to it, refused to feed it with more ruminations.He wonderedhe should have taken Eilidh on this pilgrimage of healing. But yes, her presence with him, and his love for her, was the light in his soul that kept the dark creature at bay.He would be present for her and walk with her to the summit of the faerie hill. She wanted to leave the faeries a gt and a wish. Finn did too.ldquoYou ready for that walk up the faerie hill  he called out to his daughter. She nodded excitedly with a joyful smile.September Finnrsquos phone call to his mum before they left Strathyre suggested he was coping with the temporary separation. He hadnrsquot wanted to climb the faerie hill, but Izzy hoped hersquod be up for a walk up to the rock of the boar when they got to Balquhidder.It was still early morning as they crossed the old Stron Bridge and a stunning view of Loch Voil greeted them.Mist spiralled from the water and swirled around the trees on the steep braes either side. But it was already warm, with more blue sky than grey above the mist. It was set to be one of those glorious September sunny days, the kind you appreciate all the more because you know it may be the last for a long time. They stood awhile watching the mist play above the loch, as the mountains slowly revealed themselves. The Highlands wake slowly in the morning.Izzyrsquos soul tingled as she soaked in the beauty of the moment and breathed in the sweet air.ldquoCan you smell that Finn, the scent of the Highlands  she said.Finn raised his head and snfed: ldquoSmells like cow dung.He was right, it did now. A waft of it came from a nearby field where cattle grazed. Izzy laughed.ldquoAye, well, thatrsquos the historic smell of the Highlands too!She led Finn back to the old bridge they had just driven over. Its three arches spanned the river with historic elegance.They sat on the walls looking down at the water and Izzy took it as an opportunity to tell Finn about the drovers, how in days of old they would come this way, driving hundreds of cows to markets in the south, crossing rivers and traversing through glens.Theyrsquod often sleep outside with the cattle, or sometimes in droversrsquo inns. They were the cowboys of the old Highlands, who knew the land and the dferent hazards of each route, but didnrsquot wear Stetsons of course, and rarely had a horse.She pointed towards the hills to the north: ldquoOver there was a droversrsquo route, bringing the cattle this way. The drovers could veer round and steer the cattle east of the river, but with this bridge theyrsquod have been able to cross here, then again at Strathyre downriver. There were lots of dferent ways, and the drovers had detailed maps inside their heads drawn by experience. Cattle were so valuable they would often be lted by one clan from another.Finn looked bemused.ldquoLted  Like carried on their shoulders  Izzy burst out laughing at the image and Finn looked hurt.ldquoAw, sorry Finn, I wasnrsquot laughing at you, I was laughing at the image you painted in my imagination. Lted means, well, stolen. But people called it lting because it was seen as a tradition rather than a crime. At least by those doing the lting!Finn looked around, still feeling a bit raw by his auntrsquos reaction to his question.ldquoI havenrsquot watched TV for a whole day now, he said, realising hersquod missed his breakfast TV programme. He picked up a pebble and dropped it into the water below, then watched the circles expand.ldquoWhere we going today  he asked.ldquoWell, letrsquos see how far we get, but right now we are heading for Balquhidder Kirk!ldquoWhere the minister who wrote the book on faeries was ldquoAye, but there is much more to its story.Izzy took her rucksack from the roof box.ldquoSo we are walking there ldquoYep, itrsquos really not far, his aunt replied.But Finn was wary. Her rucksack seemed suspiciously full for a short walk.They set off along the quiet single track road. The air buzzed with le and mooing from the cattle had replaced the sound of traffic. Soon they had crossed a small old bridge and were heading into a wood. They were at the base of Kirton Glen and the sound of a waterfall touched Finnrsquos senses.Izzy paused only briefly at the falls but Finn wanted to linger.ldquoWersquoll come back this way, and then we can spend some time here, she said.She pointed ahead of her: ldquoJust there, through the trees, is where we are headed. I always think this is the best way to approach this ancient place to emerge from a wood after being doused with the sound of running water, rather than just arrive from a car park and... well, yoursquoll see.The path opened up onto a gravel drive and a Victorian church. He followed Izzy round the corner of the church and found himself standing on the edge of an ancient graveyard.Old gravestones littered the ground, which was uneven. A gravestone in the form of an ancient Celtic cross stood out against the blue sky.Generation upon generation lay beneath his feet. The graves surrounded the ruins of a th-century kirk. The historic site was framed by distant mountains. His aunt was right about the approach Finn felt like Indiana Jones emerging from the jungle to discover a long-lost ruined temple.Izzy led Finn carefully past the graves and into the ruins, then through the open doorway of the old kirk. Before them were three old recumbent gravestones lying side by side, surrounded by a low metal railing.A modern-looking gravestone above the graves had an inscription: ldquoMacGregor Despite them.Finn read the smaller inscriptions. They told that these were the graves of Rob Roy, his we and two of his sons. Someone had laid flowers at the foot of the graves.ldquoHe was a legendary outlaw, explained Izzy, ldquoa member of the MacGregor clan, who were hunted like the wolf.ldquoWhy ldquoThe whole clan was outlawed, which is why there is that inscription, which means despite their persecution they survived. Rob Roy lived part of his le as a hunted man, some say he was the enemy of the rich and a defender of the poor. Irsquove heard him called Scotlandrsquos Robin Hood.ldquoSo he was a hero.ldquoWell, he is to some. But to others he was a villain, a thief and a nasty killer.ldquoWhich is true, was he a goodie or a baddie ldquoPerhaps a bit of both, depending on who you are and what you believe.ldquoWhat do you believe aunty  asked Finn. Izzy pursed her lips in thought.ldquoWell, I love the romantic stories about him, like how he gave the minister here a sheep and cow each year infor him not increasing his fees to the local people.ldquo The fact the animals were probably lted didnrsquot seem to bother the minister. People want these stories to be true because we want our heroes to be always heroic and good, and not disappoint us. But other stories show him in a very ugly light.ldquo I want him to be a hero, said Finn, ldquobut now I donrsquot know what to believe.ldquoPerhaps we can admit to ourselves that even our heroes arenrsquot always perfect and have flaws, and so sometimes they do the wrong things.Finn shrugged his shoulders: ldquoWhatrsquos flaws ldquoErm, an imperfection, or fault.Finn looked down and scuffed the ground with his boots. Izzy knew this was a challenge to how he saw the world.ldquoI want to show you something , she said.She led him to the edge of the graveyard, then pointed up at a rocky ridge which emerged from a wood on a steep brae above them.ldquoCan you see, up there, the clf face with the ledge above  Thatrsquos called Creag an Tuirc, which means the rock of the boar. It looks out over the glen and was the clan rallying point for the MacLarens who lived here. Itrsquos a special place, Irsquom hoping you will chum me up to it. I have snacks we can have when we get there.Finn looked unsure. It seemed a steep uphill walk.ldquoItrsquos a place that knows the secrets of this glen because itrsquos quietly seen everything.ldquoSecrets ldquoAye, like the mystery of Rob Royrsquos grave, and what really happened when those Buchanan clansmen arrived here looking for a fight.ldquoWhat mystery Izzy just gave Finn a teasing smile.ldquoAnd it gives you amazing views. she added.ldquoAs good as from that Celtic fort and the giantrsquos stone yesterday  asked Finn, who was wavering.ldquoIrsquod say even better.Finn ed her smile with a cheeky one: ldquoCan I have a snack now to give me energy Izzy chuckled: ldquoSure!She put her rucksack down, and took out a chocolate bar: ldquoHow about this Izzy pulled on her rucksack and started to walk out the graveyard. Finn followed while enjoying the bar.They walked together up the path that leads to Creag an Tuirc.Here are the links to chapters one, two, three, four and five.

title: family-reunited-lost-wedding-pictures-1957
story: Wendy Carroll, of Port Seton, posted the photographs on social media after her husband Brian came across an album while working in the attic of their daughter Chloersquos home on Musselburghrsquos Delta Road, which she moved to one-and-a-half years ago.Wendy said: ldquoI love old photos so he brought it home for me to look at.ldquoWhen I saw them, they were gorgeous and just full of memories.She decided to track down the family but, due to the Covid- pandemic, her search was put on hold until recently, when the photos were uploaded to social media.Wendy said the response was ldquoamazing and, within half an hour, someone recognised the wedding party.The photos were of the marriage of Musselburgh woman Una McCann and Tommy Brodie , from Armadale, on June , , at Our Lady of Loretto and St Michael Church, Musselburgh.Tommy was in the RAF, stationed in Ayr, and Una and her friend went on holiday to Ayr, where she met him at the Bobby Jones dance hall.Their only child, Monica Warnock , a Wallyford resident, collected the album from Wendy the next day.Wendy said: ldquoI was so happy toit to where it belonged.Mum-of-three Monica, who has four grandchildren, was delighted to have the album back, saying her parents orced and both remarried.She said that her half-brother Russell Brodie, who lives with his we Jenni in Edinburgh, had never seen a photograph of his grandmother, who was in the wedding photo, standing at the groomrsquos side.Monica said: ldquoMy mother gave me the album  years ago. My daughter Michaela Malone had the album in her house and it somehow ended up in the attic.ldquoShe moved from Delta Road to Ormiston about three years ago and it was left in the attic by mistake.ldquoNo one realised it was missing. Wendyrsquos husband was doing work in the attic when he found it.She added that, when the photos went on Facebook, her cousins alerted her.Una , a great-grandmother-of-five, now , lives in Edinburghrsquos Craigentinny with her husband Jack. title: nicola-sturgeon-misled-parliament---mean-comes-next
story: The Holyrood inquiry into the affair found the First Minister gave "an inaccurate account" of her actions and so misled the cross-party investigation.However, it stopped short of saying she did so "knowingly", the threshold for resignation under the Scottish Ministerial Code.It is understood the inquiry split down party lines - on the issue on Thursday, and decided Ms Sturgeon broke the code on the balance of probabilities, with only SNP MSPs clearing their leader.Why was the committee established It was set up after a successful judicial review by former first minister Mr Salmond resulted in the Scottish Governmentrsquos investigation of harassment allegations against him being ruled unlawful and ldquotainted by apparent bias, with a pound, payout being awarded to him for legal fees in .MSPs have taken evidence from Mr Salmond and Ms Sturgeon, from civil servants, including repeated sessions from Permanent Secretary Leslie Evans, trade unions and from SNP chief executive Peter Murrell ndash who is current First Minister Ms Sturgeonrsquos husband.Why did Mr Salmond take legal action The former first minister did not feel his treatment by the Scottish Government was fair.It was later found that the lead investigator of the complaints had prior contact with some of the female complainers, leading Judge Lord Pentland to say the investigation was ldquotainted with apparent bias.How has the inquiry gone The committee has repeatedly voiced frustration about the slow handing over of evidence from a number of parties.The Scottish Government was accused of obstruction last year, with the committee saying it was ldquocompletely frustrated with the lack of evidence.Both the committee and the Scottish Government were at loggerheads over legal advice provided as part of the judicial review process. MSPs wanted to know when the Scottish Government was advised it would likely lose the challenge raised by Mr Salmond, but ministers said handing over the advice would breach the ministerial code.On two occasions, MSPs voted for the evidence to be released, with a deal eventually being struck in December to reveal the advice only to MSPs on the committee.Following a vote of no confidence threat in the Deputy First Minister, the Scottish Government released ldquokey legal advice, but the Scottish Tories were not satisfied and continued in their bid to oust John Swinney, which ultimately failed.Mr Salmond and Ms Sturgeon separately sat for mammoth sessions in front of the committee, taking questions from MSPs over several hours.Didnrsquot Mr Salmond face trial on sexual misconduct charges Yes. The former first minister was cleared of  charges at the High Court in Edinburgh in March last year after being arrested in January .What were the issues with Mr Salmondrsquos evidence to the committee Mr Salmond and the committee have been caught in repeated legal wrangles over evidence published by the inquiry.Last month, the former first minister said he would not appear before the committee after it decided not to publish his submission to a separate investigation into whether Ms Sturgeon breached the ministerial code over fears it may identy some of the complainers in Mr Salmondrsquos criminal trial last year.However, an alteration made to a court order by Judge Lady Dorrian meant the evidence could potentially be made public.While the committee voted against publication, the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Bodymade the decision to publish anyway.The evidence was online for less than  hours before the Crown Office raised concerns with Holyrood about it, asking for redactions to be made.In his submission, the former first minister accused some in the Scottish Government and SNP of a ldquomalicious and concerted attempt to damage my reputation and remove me from public le in Scotland.But Ms Sturgeon said her predecessor did not have ldquoa shred of evidence to support his claims.The submission was later re-released, with a number of paragraphs relating to the set-up of a meeting between Mr Salmond and his successor redacted.Is the committee inquiry the only investigation into the matter No. Ms Sturgeon is currently under investigation by James Hamilton QC to establishshe breached the ministerial code.Ms Sturgeon referred herself after being accused of misleading Parliament over when she knew of the complaints against Mr Salmond.She previously said she had been told about the allegations by Mr Salmond himself during a meeting in her home on April , .However, it was later found that Mr Salmondrsquos former chief of staff Geoff Aberdein had met with the First Minister in her Holyrood office four days prior to that, where she was told of the complaints.Scotlandrsquos first minister @NicolaSturgeon responds to @SkyNews exclusive the harassment committee has ruled she misled Parliament in her evidence.ldquoThe opposition members of this committee made their minds up about me before I uttered a single word of evidence. pic UNeUJsWhat has the committee concluded A leak on Thursday evening from inside the committee revealed it has concluded the First Minister misled the inquiry over whether she had offered to intervene in the case ndash which Ms Sturgeon denies doing.Two other witnesses, one of whom is Mr Salmondrsquos lawyer and former SNP MSP Duncan Hamilton and who was at the meeting in question, contradicted the First Ministerrsquos statement.The conclusion was arrived at following a - party line vote, with the four SNP members of the committee, including convener Linda Fabiani, supporting the First Ministerrsquos assertion.What happens next The decision is likely to increase pressure on Ms Sturgeon to stand down before Mayrsquos election, although it is unclear whether the act was deemed a resignation-worthy offence.Last night, Scottish Conservatives leader Douglas Ross called for her to quit.He said: ldquoThe committee will publish its findings in the coming days and we will wait for that report.ldquoBut we have already detailed that Nicola Sturgeon lied to the Scottish Parliament and for that, she must resign. All wersquore waiting for is confirmation.Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar said: ldquoI am not going to prejudge the outcome of the committee report and we await its findings, butit does conclude that the First Minister has misled Parliament and potentially breached the ministerial code then that is incredibly serious.A Scottish Parliament spokesperson said: "Further to media reports on the Committeersquos findings, the Committee is still finalising its report. There will be no further comment on the report ahead of its publication.It is expected to be published on Tuesday.What has Nicola Sturgeon said Nicola Sturgeon has said a ldquovery partisan leak from the Alex Salmond inquiry is ldquonot that surprising as the committee is understood to have deemed she misled parliament.She told Sky News last night: ldquoI stand by all of the evidence I gave to the committee, all eight hoursrsquo worth of evidence.ldquoWhatrsquos been clear is that opposition members of this committee made their minds up about me before I muttered a single word of evidence, their public comments have made that clear.ldquoSo this leak from the committee ndash very partisan leak ndash tonight before theyrsquove finalised the report is not that surprising.She added that she is awaiting the result of the James Hamilton QC investigation into whether she broke the ministerial code.A spokesman for the First Minister previously added: ldquoThe First Minister told the truth to the committee in eight hours of evidence, and stands by that evidence.ldquoIt is clear from past public statements that opposition members of this committee had prejudged the First Minister at the outset of the inquiry and before hearing a word of her evidence, so this partisan and selective briefing ndash before the committee has actually published its final report ndash is hardly surprising.ldquoThe question of the First Ministerrsquos adherence to the ministerial code is being considered independently by James Hamilton, and we expect to receive and publish his report soon.

title: musselburgh-sea-cadets-virtual-walk-london-back
story: Along with family members, they are logging their steps or kilometres, completed daily during March, via an online tracker which calculates the distance walked for each day.They had originally planned to walk km, from Musselburgh to London, but smashed their target distance and started thejourney back to the Honest Toun ndash a total of ,km.They have already raised nearly pound,.Chief Officer Mark Tfin , from Gorebridge, is supporting the unit ndash TS Indefatigable ndash by taking part in the virtual sponsored walk while on his Maersk Line Hamburg Sud ship off Chinarsquos coast, covering more than km.Funds raised will be used to provide training when the cadetsto their newly refurbished unit building on South Street after Covid- restrictions are eased.The property has undergone a full upgrade costing pound, to include new toilet and shower facilities, offices and classroom space. Improved teaching equipment such as interactive teaching boards have also been installed.Funding of pound, was received from the Marine Society and Sea Cadets, pound, from Viridor, pound, from the Musselburgh Common Good Fund and pound, from fundraising and donations.Petty Officer Belle Milliken said: ldquoDue to the current pandemic, the unit has lost out on a lot of our usual fundraising route and, with the team taking part in the sponsored walk, it will enable them to get out, get fit, improve wellbeing and spend time with family as part of their team.She said: ldquoThe money will support ourto parading, purchasing training equipment for the cadets in face-to-face classes, and upkeep for the current equipment and boats.The group provides --year-olds with a range of opportunities, from first aid to boating qualications, all based around the Royal Navy.PO Milliken said the cadets were looking forward to ing to normal activities after the Covid- crisis.She said: ldquoWe were hoping tolate last year but, due to awaiting final certication for the building work, this was put on hold.ldquoAt the moment we are parading as normal but on Zoom and delivering specialisation training in communication systems, promotion training, first aid, engineering, Duke of Edinburgh, boating theory, catering, BTEC and CVQO.ldquoWe have also had sessions delivered by the Royal Navy engagement team on careers and flags at sea, which is a Royal Navy communication session.One cadet said: ldquoPersonally, joining sea cadets was one of the best things I have done.ldquoIt has provided me with a confidence and experiences that just simply cannot be learnt within a classroom.ldquoIt has given me an insight into Royal Navy le and has helped me meet many friends from all across the UK who will be friends for le.Anyone wishing to donate to the sponsored walk can go to gofundme f musselburgh-sea-cadets-sponsored-virtual-walk-

title: teenager-launches-petition-bins-wallyford
story: While out walking his Jack Russell terrier Madi, Corgan James-Robertson, , noticed a shortage of bins around the village after moving there with his family in March last year.He is concerned about the amount of dog dirt and poo bags left lying around, as well as rubbish including plastic items such as bottles.He hopes the petition, which currently has more than  signatures, will encourage the council to provide more bins in the area.Corgan, a pupil at Portobello High School, said that there were recycling bins everywhere in Portobello, where he used to live, so it was easy to dispose of drink bottles and cans.He said: ldquoIn Wallyford there are none and only one rubbish bin ndash not even the bus stops have bins near them.He added: ldquoEver since I moved to Wallyford in March , I have noticed that there is a shortage of bins around Wallyford.ldquoThere is a lot of dog faeces, plastics rubbish and dog poo bags left lying around.ldquoI would like to get the attention of East Lothian Council to get more bins that would include recycling and rubbish.Even Madi is helping with the initiative, as the environmentally conscious canine always recycles a discarded bottle while out for a walk by bringing one home each time .Corganrsquos mum Samantha said: ldquoWe just noticed that there were so many lying everywhere.Corgan decided to take action and has sent his petition to local MSP Colin Beattie, and plans to write to East Lothian Council at the end of his campaign.The family are ldquofirm believers in recycling and the effects of discarded plastic bottles and bags on the environment.The petition is available to view online at change.org p east-lothian-council-to-get-more-bins-in-wallyford

story: Elspeth Ogilvie came out tops in the vocal section and Oliver Massey, playing the trumpet, was first in the instrumental section.The annual event, usually held in Loretto Schoolrsquos chapel, took place via Zoom due to Covid-. title: call-new-fishmongers-open-haddington
story: Haddington has been without a permanent fishmonger for a number of years, with the town visited by two mobile fish vans which stop off three times each week.Now, members of the townrsquos community council are debating whether the increased use of fresh food, including fish, in cooking would tip the scale in favour of a new shop.A number of community councillors told a virtual meeting that they used the vans when they came to the town, with many members equally convinced that a shop would do well.Therese Laing felt that times had changed and people were buying more fresh goods, including fish.Pat Lemmon, vice-chairwoman of the group, added: ldquoIf there was a market for a fish shop or a fruit and veg shop, it would be lovely to see them in the town centre.The town centre currently has very few empty units, despite the challenges brought by the coronavirus pandemic.Fiona Frances-Adams, also a community councillor, was among those who felt a quality fishmonger could be successful in Haddington.She said a previous fishmonger had not stocked much shellfish, adding: ldquoThey said there was no market for it.ldquoIf you donrsquot try the market, there will not be one. I still thinkyou get a fish shop with a lot more choice, top choice, like Clark Bros in Musselburgh on a smaller scale, it would do very well.Fellow member Jack Worden stressed that the quality of the seafood on offer was crucial to determiningthe business would be a success.He said: ldquoI sadly did not go into the fish shop but go to the fish van because the quality is so much better. If there is a market for a fish shop, it will come.Despite the debate, Chris McEwan, chairman of the group, stressed that the idea was outwith their remit.He said: ldquoThe community council does not really do fish shops! It is the sort of thing that would have to work with councillors and council. Maybe the next time a fish van is there, mention to them they would make a roaring tradethere was a shop.Carolyn Algeo ran JC Seafood and Paulrsquos Fish Shop, alongside husband Paul, in the town centre until about .She now runs JC Seafood in Port Seton and felt the increasing number of fish vans meant it would be dficult for a permanent fishmongerrsquos in Haddington.She said: ldquoIt would be a complete uphill struggle.ldquoThere are many vans coming in from all over the area.

title: pupils-get-insight-world-finance-apprentice-scheme
story: Pupils from Dunbar Grammar School, North Berwick High School and Preston Lodge High School have spent lockdown preparing for the world of work by undertaking foundation apprenticeships in providing financial services with Social Investment Scotland .Rachel Miller, who attends Preston Lodge Dunbar Grammar pupil Abbie Chisholm and Emma Roy, of North Berwick High, have been working towards the qualication for the last  months alongside their regular schoolwork.They have had to balance the demands of the apprenticeship programme with online learning during the pandemic.Foundation apprenticeships were launched in  to help S and S pupils gain work experience while still at school, with the qualication equivalent to an SQA Higher.They are offered to senior school pupils as part of the curriculum when making their subject choices.The pupils have already achieved a National Progression Award after completing the classroom-style learning segment of the course, which was delivered by Limelight Careers on behalf of East Lothian Council.A large part of the programme usually involves a work-based placement however, given the work-from-home guidance, many of the placements with financial services providers have been put on hold.SIS stepped in to offer the pupils an opportunity to join the team virtually.Emma, , enjoyed the experience. She said: ldquoOver the last year, regular schoolwork and exams have been so up in the air, but itrsquos been reassuring to have the apprenticeship programme going on at the same time, which will give me a formal qualication.ldquoIrsquove developed my knowledge of finance throughout the programme but have also had the opportunity to build confidence and practice other skills like teamwork and communication.SIS was one of the first financial organisations in Scotland to support this kind of foundation apprenticeship for school pupils.In the last two years, the organisation has welcomed six pupils to its team as part of their learning experience, supporting them on their journey into employment.Lindsay Wake, head of impact at SIS, said: ldquoWersquove been impressed with the pupilsrsquo resilience and willingness to learn, despite the uncertainty of the world around them, and we hope to see them continue on to exciting and rewarding careers in the financial services sector.

title: merryhatton-column-great-plants-getting-children-gardening
story: This month, wersquore taking a look at some plants that theyrsquoll find easy to grow, starting from seed.If this is a childrsquos first experience of gardening, you might want to consider seeds that will germinate easily and quickly.For example, microgreens can be grown indoors, germinating and ready to eat within only days from sowing.Salad leaves such as lettuce can be sown indoors at this time of year and finished outdoors once the weather is warmer. After the frosts are gone, they can be grown from seed outdoors, either in pots or beds.Since lettuce can be ready to eat within as little as six weeks from sowing, itrsquos a good idea to sow a few seeds every week or two to ensure a continuous supply of salad throughout summer.For more experienced young gardeners, round carrots are a relatively quick crop that grow well in pots. Varieties like lsquoParis Marketrsquo produce tasty snacks that can be harvested - weeks from sowing.A slightly longer crop but nevertheless very popular is the pumpkin ndash sow the seeds now and theyrsquoll be a fine size for carving lanterns and making pumpkin pie in the autumn. Once they begin to fill out, they are fascinating to watch as they grow almost visibly from day to day!The choice of flower seeds is too extensive to list here, so wersquove highlighted three of the easiest and most rewarding to consider.Nasturtiums are possibly the most popular amongst flower seeds for young gardeners. These large seeds are easy for children to handle, can be germinated indoors during early spring and planted outdoors in pots or borders when the risk of frost is gone.Flowering from June right through to October, the flowers and leaves can be used in salads. By removing dead heads, repeat flowering is encouraged. They produce seed very easily and itrsquos entirely possible that you might find nasturtiums unexpectedly popping up again next year!The ever-popular poppy is another favourite and our recommendation here are the lsquoLittle Ladybirdrsquo poppies ndash with their black-spotted centres on bright red flowers, you can almost imagine that they are a family of ladybirds!When thinking about flowers that can be easily grown from seed, itrsquos impossible to ignore sweet peas.Try creating your very own sweet pea tepee with a few bamboos and some twine. Plant the sweet peas around the base of the tepee , then train the plants up and around as they grow to create a tent with living walls. With endless fragrant flowers and a tepee to play in, itrsquos sure to be a winner for all the family!For many of todayrsquos gardeners, their own plot in the garden is where their love of gardening first began.Whilst not every garden has the space to have a dedicated kids area, therersquos often room to let children grow things in containers.Why not set them the challenge of finding the most unusual colourful imaginative container and see what they come up with  Old toys, kitchen containers or even old shoes and boots can be fun containers to grow plants in and could be decorated to produce wonderfully inidual planters. Just make sure that theyrsquore clean before you begin, that they have sufficient drainage so that the plants donrsquot become waterlogged and that they will remain intact when watered.If you donrsquot have a garden, perhaps you could let them experiment with houseplants or a window box With so much evidence about the benefits to our wellbeing of gardening, introducing children to this wonderful pastime is certainly worth considering. You may be launching a future horticulturalist or simply helping them learn how gardening can help them remain healthy and well but itrsquos certainly worth having a go!Although we are currently closed due to Government guidance, our plant team are here in the garden centre caring for the plants and can be contacted by email at info@merryhatton or telephonefor help and advice. Yoursquoll also find lots of information and can purchase your seeds on our website at www.merryhatton

title: puppet-animation-festival-returning-east-lothian-easter
story: This year it moves online due to the Covid- pandemic, replacing the performances and workshops for primary school children which usually take place in venues throughout the country.Organised by The Brunton in Musselburgh and East Lothian Councilrsquos arts service, the festival will feature two performances to watch through the theatrersquos website and two fun workshops to take part in via Zoom.The Incredible Tale of Robot Boy, by Theatre Rites, one of the UKrsquos leading theatre companies, will be shown on Saturday, April , at .am and pm for ages eight plus.In the most extraordinary high-tech laboratory, a team of the worldrsquos top scientists are attempting the impossible ndash to create a robot with a real brain. Their aim is to push the boundaries of scientic discovery. They succeed and Robot Boy is born.It is described as ldquoa poetic story about humanity, responsibility and le, with dazzling puppetry, interactive film and performance.The Selfish Giant, by Tessa Bide Productions, Bristolrsquos leading family theatre experts, is on Saturday, April , at .am and pm for ages three plus.Inspired by the touching childrenrsquos story The Selfish Giant by Oscar Wilde, it uses powerful storytelling, captivating puppetry, beautul design, enchanting music and a sprinkling of audience interaction to explore an unusual friendship and how even the grumpiest giantrsquos heart can melt when spring finally arrives.Tickets for the two shows are pound each . This is per viewing ndash regardless of the number of people watching together at the same time.Two fun and interactive workshops presented by Temporary Commons offer the chance to stay connected and get creative. Bookers will receive a pack with all the materials needed, as well as a Zoom link to join the workshop online, led by professional puppet creators.Sing Song Bird Puppet workshop is on Saturday, April , at am and pm, for ages eight plus.Using collage and pop-up card-folding techniques, participants will make a bird puppet with a moving beak. These birds love to sing, squawk and chatter. The birds sing a simple song which will be shared at the end of the workshop.The Wibble Wobble Clown workshop is on Saturday, April , at am and .pm, for ages five plus.These puppets are collages made from simple shapes, then assembled with split pins. Once theyrsquore made, the clowns will parade, to test their tipple topple, wibble wobble.Each workshop costs pound per participant, which includes postage of all the materials needed, as well as access to the professional-led online workshops.Michael Stitt, chairman of The Brunton Theatre Trust, said: ldquoThe Brunton has worked hard throughout the pandemic to find and provide the best possible performancesand workshops for our audiences. We hope our work with the festival will bring enjoyment and pleasure at this challenging time for us all.A spokesperson for Puppet Animation Festival said: ldquoThis year has been incredibly challenging for both young people and their parents across the country, with issues of isolation, lack of social contact, exhaustion and diminished support networks affecting most families in the UK.ldquoItrsquos therefore more important than ever to find moments of playfulness, escape and creativity, which is why Puppet Animation Festival will offer the chance for families to watch high-quality work and to get creative themselves.Puppet festival events can be booked with The Brunton by phone on    or online at www.thebrunton

title: cant-choose-covid-vaccine-get
story: There has been a lot of discussion around the side effects of the AstraZeneca vaccine, however ministries across the globe have been quick to quash any fears saying that it is "safe and effective".Prime Minister Boris Johnson will receive the Oxford jabas he urges the country to get vaccinated.The news of Mr Johnson receiving the AstraZeneca vaccine comes as a host of European countries announced they would begin using the jab once again following new safety assurances.A number of countries including Germany and France have reversed their decision to temporarily pause the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine over blood clot concerns after the European Medicines Agencycalled the vaccine ldquosafe and effective.France, Italy and Germany, along with Cyprus, Latvia and Lithuania, have confirmed they will resume rollout of the Oxford shot on Friday.While Spain, Portugal and the Netherlands said they will follow suit next week, although Spain said it could exclude certain groups.But do you have a choice in the matter  Can you pick and choose which of the currently approved vaccines you are injected withyou have worries about a particular one Here is everything you need to know about it:No.The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation has not advised a preference between the Pfizer-BioNTech, the Oxford-AstraZeneca or any other vaccines in the UKpopulation, stating that "both give very high protection against severe disease... and both vaccines have good safety profiles".The UKrsquos vaccine programme is offering vaccines in line with the supply of vaccines, and so the option to choose is not availablesay the NHS.In certain circumstances, you may be advised to have a certain vaccine by a medical professional, but this is not common, and will be discussed with you fully before hand you cannot request a certain vaccine for yourself.Earlier this week, Northern Irelandrsquos Health Minister made clear people cannot pick and choose what type of Covid- vaccine they receive as he moved to provide reassurance on the safety of the AstraZeneca jab.Robin Swann highlighted that the UKrsquos Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agencyhad found no evidence of a link between the vaccine and reported cases of blood clots in some European countries.Asked whether people who had concerns about the AstraZeneca jab could select a dferent type of vaccine, Swann said, ldquotherersquos no opportunity to pick and choose vaccines within our current programme.You will have to have two doses of the same vaccine.The MHRA has concluded that any link between the jab and clots is unproven The World Health Organisationis urging countries to continue using the AstraZeneca Covid- vaccine as global medical leaders meet to discuss reports of blood clots.Dr Soumya Swaminathan, WHOrsquos chief scientist, told a media briefing ldquowe do not want people to panic, as she said no association has been found so far between blood clots and Covid- vaccines.She said the rates at which blood clots have occurred in people who received the AstraZeneca vaccine ldquoare in fact less than what you would expect in the general population.Professor Anthony Harnden, deputy chairman of the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation, said there was ldquono demonstrable dference in the number of blood clots seen between the general population and the  million who have so far received the Oxford AstraZeneca jab to date.He told BBC Breakfast ldquobecause wersquore immunising so many people, we are bound to see blood clots at the same time as the vaccination.ldquoThatrsquos not because they are due to the vaccination. Thatrsquos because they occur naturally in the population. We have to remember that there are , blood clots a month on average in the general population.ldquoOne ought to also remember that Covid causes blood clots, added Prof Harnden. ldquoSo, the risks of not having the Covid vaccination far outweigh the risks from the vaccinations.The EMA has concluded there is no overall increase in the risk of blood clots with the vaccine Of course, taking up the offer of a Covid- vaccine remains voluntary, and there are currently no plans to make being immunised.But members of the public are being urged to accept offers of a jab as soon as they can, and being reassured that all vaccines available are safe, and have been developed under the usual strict, regulatory practices.Peter Openshaw, professor of experimental medicine at Imperial College London, said the decision to pause rollout of the Oxford AstraZeneca jab could be a ldquodisaster for Covid- vaccine uptake in Europe.Asked what he would say to those in the UK who are booked to receive an Oxford jab, Prof Openshaw told BBC Radio rsquos Today programme: ldquoI really wouldnrsquot be worried at the present time.ldquoI think it is very clear that the benefits of being vaccinated at the moment so far outweigh the possible concern over this rather rare type of blood clot, he added. ldquoI think it is a disaster for the vaccination uptake in Europe, which is already on slightly unsteady ground in some countries.

story: Prominent buildings and landmarks throughout the UK will be illuminated as part of the national day of reflection, including the Kelpies, Wallace Monument and Ness Bridge.End of le charity Marie Curie is organising the event, which is being backed by more than  organisations, including the emergency services, businesses, charities and community groups.The Scottish Government is among those supporting the event and is inviting people to take part and to reach out to someone they know is grieving.Ken Macintosh, the Scottish Parliamentrsquos presiding officer, will lead the minutersquos silence on the garden lobby steps at Holyrood at  noon along with party leaders.Also, many people have lost loved ones to causes other than Covid over the past  months. The restrictions in place have made the grieving process even more dficult than it would have been - my thoughts are with you too.People are later being encouraged to stand on their doorsteps at pm with phones, candles and torches to signy a ldquobeacon of remembrance.The latest National Records of Scotland figures indicate , deaths were registered in Scotland where Covid- was mentioned on the death certicate, as of March .First Minister Nicola Sturgeon previously said it is ldquoright we pause to remember those we have lost, and offer our continued thoughts, solidarity and support to the bereaved.She added: ldquoAs we remember, we can also reflect on how far we have come in a relatively short period of time, and begin to look toward the future.ldquoBecause of our collective sacrice, there are people alive now who would otherwise have lost their le to the virus and we now have vaccines, offering us hope that we can soon get back to a more normal way of le.ldquoBy supporting one another and sticking with restrictions a little longer, we will get out of this crisis andto a world where we can properly see friends and loved ones again, travel freely, and work, socialise and go on holiday once more.

title: seven-year-old-girl-abandoned-tears-mile-home-bus-driver
story: The primary three pupil at Yester Primary School is said to live between Gford and Garvald and was on the school bus home last Friday afternoon, a service run by Prentice Buses.According to eyewitnesses, the bus driver did not stop at her address she is then said to have told the driver that he missed her stop, a statement he is said to have ignored.Older pupils on the bus are then said to have also pleaded with the driver to turn the bus around and drop the child off at her home, which he allegedly also ignored.The driver is then said to have continued on the route to Garvald, where he dropped off some pupils as well as the child affected. Garvald is about two miles from her home.Eyewitnesses say that the child was left ldquodistraught, ldquocrying and very scared and despite the children shouting at the driver, they say he drove away and ldquoabandoned her in Garvald, with no way home and walking the only alternative.Another parent is said to have taken her home.Prentice Busesrsquo managing director has said that the driver was unaware the child was wanting to get off at the stop but steps were being taken to ensure such an incident didnrsquot happen again.The childrsquos grandmother, Susan Smeaton, called the incident ldquonegligence as ldquodrivers have a duty of care to make sure the kids are safely dropped off at their homes.She added: ldquoThere are no pavements on the rural area, anything could have happened to her.ldquoIf it had been last week with just the primary one to primary threes at school, she would have been in that village on her own. This is not acceptable.A complaint has been lodged by the childrsquos family to East Lothian Council following the incident and investigations are continuing.Ross Prentice, managing director of Prentice Buses, said that the route was one the company had been running for nearly  years.He said that to his knowledge and from speaking to his driver, no one shouted back at them and no one said anything to them.He said that the driver shouted back to aska child was getting off at the stop but, as he did not hear any response and there was no parent waiting ndash something the family denies ndash they continued on to the next stop, where several children got off.On turning round and passing through Garvald again, they saw no children waiting.Mr Prentice said that it was not unusual for children to get off at dferent stops, for examplethey were going to visit a friend.He added thatthe driver saw the child crying he would have gone back and dropped her off at her home rather than leaving her behind.Mr Prentice said: ldquoSafety is very important to us, we do not take it lightly and want to make sure that this does not happen again.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe received a complaint from the family about this incident and officers are investigating the issues raised with the contractor concerned.ldquoWe take seriously our responsibilities to all the children and young people who use our home to school transport.ldquoAs this is the subject of ongoing discussions as part of our formal complaints process, it would be inappropriate for us to comment further.
